snippet: Dale Murphy and Andre Dawson, two slugging outfielders from the 1980s, are on the Hall of Fame ballot. But one is close to being bumped off.
lead_paragraph: Two well-respected slugging outfielders from the 1980s are once more on the Hall of Fame ballot. One has inched ever closer to the required 75 percent approval from voters and is probably eagerly awaiting the announcement of the new class Wednesday. The other is close to being bumped off the ballot for too little support. Andre Dawson, who starred for the Montreal Expos and the Chicago Cubs, hit 438 home runs, winning the 1977 Rookie of the Year award and the 1987 Most Valuable Player award over his 21-season career. He was an eight-time Gold Glover with a golden arm to match. In his first year on the ballot, in 2002, he received 45.3 percent of the votes but he climbed to 67.3 percent last year. Dale Murphy, the longtime Atlanta Braves star, managed only 19.3 percent of the votes in his first year (1999) and declined to 11.5 percent in 2009. Murphy had 1,700 fewer plate appearances than Dawson because of injuries, but he hit 398 home runs, won Most Valuable Player awards in 1982 and 1983, and was awarded five Gold Gloves in center over 18 seasons. He is typically considered a ''close but no'' guy, his brief stretch of greatness from 1982 to '87 followed by a sharp decline. He had four good years before his peak, but he averaged just .238 and 22 home runs in his last four full seasons. By contrast, Dawson drove in 92 runs in 1979 and was still driving in 90 in 1992.
headline: Twice An M.V.P., But Never A Shoo-In

snippet: LING--Dalthel "Moy", was born September 18, 1930 in Kingstom, Jamaica. Ms. Dalthel Ling--more affectionately known as "Aunt Moy" to her family--died due to renal failure on Christmas afternoon much like her only daughter who had succumb to cancer...
lead_paragraph: LING--Dalthel "Moy", was born September 18, 1930 in Kingstom, Jamaica. Ms. Dalthel Ling--more affectionately known as "Aunt Moy" to her family--died due to renal failure on Christmas afternoon much like her only daughter who had succumb to cancer Christmas 1997. Ms. Ling was a proud member of a rare ethnic subset, Chinese-Jamaican. Her love of her family was matched only by her love of world. She'd set foot on every continent in her lifetime, took a Safari in her 60s and even found her way to an Amsterdam cafe in her 70s. Ms. Ling was described as the family's matriarch, often the patron saint of lodging, and its businesswoman whose business often seemed to be the family itself. She is survived by her grandson, Collin Hunt, 29, granddaughter Julian Hunt, 27, and several cousins, nieces, nephews, extended relatives and dear friends. Friends may call Sunday, 5-8pm, January 3, 2010 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Service Monday, 9:30am January 4 at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations will be accepted for: The Denice Johnson Hunt Endowed Fund UW Foundation, Box 359505, Seattle, WA 98195-9505.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LING, DALTHEL "MOY"

snippet: Two volumes on saving the American university.
lead_paragraph: Champions of the market can turn up in the oddest places. At the same time that bankers and businessmen are acknowledging the downsides of unregulated capitalism, college and university reformers are urging the academy to more closely embrace the marketplace. Amid the raft of new books on the failings of higher education, some challenge the longtime separation between ivy-covered idealists and real-world demands. Scholarly disdain for getting and spending, they argue, has caused serious trouble both in the classroom and in the budget office.
abstract: Patricia Cohen article on two books on failings of higher education; The Marketplace Of Ideas: Reform and Reaction In the American University by Louis Menand offers compact history of how modern university developed and Saving Alma Mater: A Rescue Plan For America's Public Universities by James C Garland examines how to put public universities on solid financial footing; photos (M)
headline: Embracing the Marketplace

snippet: Joining the many books explaining the collapse is “I.O.U.,” in which John Lanchester suggests that Western capitalism has lost its checks and balances.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the aftereffects of the financial crisis has been a flood of books promising to explain it. There have been books by economists, journalists, politicians, Wall Street insiders and even a federal judge, Richard Posner, who has produced more than 40 other books, and evidently couldn't resist the temptation to churn out one on this subject. What has been hard to find is a book about the disaster by a writer with literary bona fides. But now comes ''I.O.U.: Why Everyone Owes Everyone and No One Can Pay,'' by John Lanchester (Simon & Schuster, $25).
abstract: Devin Leonard Off the Shelf column reviews book I.O.U.: Why Everyone Owes Everyone and No One Can Pay by John Lanchester; photo (M)
headline: A Writerly Approach To the Financial Crisis

snippet: 1. The six fractions 1/7 to 6/7 have the same repeating sequence of six numbers after the decimal point, each fraction starting with a different number in the sequence 142857. Think of these numbers as in a circle, and going around that circle...
lead_paragraph: 1. The six fractions 1/7 to 6/7 have the same repeating sequence of six numbers after the decimal point, each fraction starting with a different number in the sequence 142857. Think of these numbers as in a circle, and going around that circle forever. The first number after the decimal point in the decimal version of 1/7 is 1 (.142857); of 2/7, 2 (.285714); of 3/7, 4 (.428571); of 4/7, 5 (.571428); of 5/7, 7 (.714285); and of 6/7, 8 (.857142). Adding 1, 4, 2, 8, 5 and 7, you always get 27.
abstract: Answers to quiz on mathematical concepts; drawing; photo (M)
headline: ANSWERS

snippet: Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth...
lead_paragraph: Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth Feinberg, the government's special master for executive compensation, and they were awaiting submissions from companies that had received (and not yet paid back) billions in what federal regulations call ''exceptional assistance'' from the government's Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP. The government had the authority to set compensation levels at those seven TARP recipients, and this was the companies' opportunity to plead for salaries and bonuses for each of its top 25 executives. Chrysler Financial and General Motors submitted their proposals -- about 2,000-plus pages each -- a few days before. Now, like college kids crashing a term paper, the other five -- A.I.G., Bank of America, Chrysler, Citigroup and General Motors Acceptance Corporation -- were frantically trying to get their pitches into Treasury's digital in-box by the Aug. 14 deadline.
abstract: Steven Brill article considers differing points of view on executive pay; on one side are those who believe it is unfair that top executive earns 275 times what their average employees make; those with free-market view believe any amount agreed to by both sides is fine; third approach is more nuanced, holding that free-market idea should be regulated to ensure that shareholders are well served or at least well informed; Kenneth Feinberg, special master for executive compensation, has found culture of entitlement has become norm despite average or poor performance; defining fair compensation is onerous task and illustrates how difficult systemic reform will be; photo (L)
headline: What's a Bailed-Out Banker Really Worth?

snippet: Play Robinson Crusoe for a few days on a rented island with prices ranging from $375 a night to $53,000.
lead_paragraph: ONE night in August, Debra Dawson and her boyfriend, Joe Sinagoga, were vacationing on Jonathan Island, a nearly three-acre plot off the coast of Narragansett, R.I. Their motorboat had broken down and they had no way of getting to the mainland for dinner. A crisis? Not at all. For Ms. Dawson, a 48-year-old Manhattanite and self-described ''city chick,'' it turned into one of the most romantic nights of her life. She spent the rest of the day plucking a dozen mussels from the buoys off the dock and digging for clams on the beach. She picked tomatoes and peppers from the garden and brought everything inside to make paella. Most importantly, the couple had the island all to themselves for the week, for a reasonable $3,250, plus $500 for use of the boat.
abstract: Jonathan Vatner travel article on sampling of islands around world available for rent; list; photo (M)
headline: Island Hopping To Your Own Island

snippet: There is such a divide between the best and the worst in the National Football Conference  that every playoff spot is clinched going into the final weekend and teams are playing only for seeding. In the American Football Conference, seven teams are ...
lead_paragraph: There is such a divide between the best and the worst in the National Football Conference that every playoff spot is clinched going into the final weekend and teams are playing only for seeding. In the American Football Conference, seven teams are alive for the two wild-card spots. If you can figure out these possibilities without help, you're better than us and you're probably a mathematician. Here is what it takes for each team and how Sunday might unfold. Take a few aspirin before you dive in. JUDY BATTISTA
abstract: Seven teams are alive in American Football Conference for two wild-card spots in playoffs; photo (M)
headline: What Will It Take to Make A.F.C. Playoffs? In Most Cases, a Win and Much More

snippet: ANDROS--Gus Dick, on December 31, 2009. Born March 4, 1926 Oklahoma City. Dancer, Choreographer, teacher for over 60 years. Started dancing after discharge from army in WWII. 1948 joined San Francisco Ballet. Teachings: Theatre Arts Center, Ballet...
lead_paragraph: ANDROS--Gus Dick, on December 31, 2009. Born March 4, 1926 Oklahoma City. Dancer, Choreographer, teacher for over 60 years. Started dancing after discharge from army in WWII. 1948 joined San Francisco Ballet. Teachings: Theatre Arts Center, Ballet Master Bat Dor Dance Company Of Israel, Harkness Dance Center, High School Of The Performing Arts, New York School Of Ballet, Usdan Center For The Performing Arts, Steps, 92nd Street Y, Ballet Academy East. For 20 years Dick wrote dance history for Dance Pages and Dance And The Arts plus The Dick Andros Newsletter. For website please Goggle Gus Dick Andros to read his extraordinary career plus histories on dance. He leaves behind nieces, nephews, cousins and a multitude of adoring students and friends. Dick, you will always remain in all our hearts and minds. Peace. Memorial and boat service-later in 2010.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDROS, GUS DICK

snippet: War bonds helped pay for World Wars I and II. But they may not be such a good idea for Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: How do you pay for a war? The question re-emerged in Congress last month afterPresident Obama announced he would send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan, and it is likely to be a major issue as lawmakers return to work in January. Reaching back into the nation's history books, some lawmakers are suggesting a war bond program similar to those used during the Civil War and both World Wars. Such a program might reduce the country's reliance on foreign borrowing and avoid a tax increase.
abstract: Some economists fear that instituting war bonds program to help pay for Iraq and Afghanistan wars, as some legislators are calling for, could harm economy; suggest it would encourage people to set aside money instead of spending it, which could hamper recovery by taking money out of circulation; while many experts believe program could be morale booster, they also believe that tax increase is inevitable; photo (M)
headline: Buying a Share of Victory. Or Not.

snippet: Parents and educators should realize that too often their children’s education is in the hands of unskilled, untrained substitute teachers.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, during lunch with a second-grade teacher in the Chicago area, I mentioned that I was going to substitute teach. The teacher -- I'll call him Dan -- started into a story about his own experience with a substitute, which is easily summarized: Dan left a lesson plan; the sub didn't follow it. So, he ended by asking, how hard can substitute teaching be?
abstract: Carolyn Bucior Op-Ed article describes difficulties faced by substitute teachers; notes that many districts require little or no teacher training for substitutes; recounts failure of regular teachers to leave lesson plans or basic information about students; says high absentee rate among teachers--three times as that in other professions--should offer clue as to challenges of job; urges Congress to pass law to make federal money available to school districts to train substitutes; suggests further measures that teachers and administrators can take to help substitutes; drawing (M)
headline: The Replacements

snippet: Elizabeth Khinda and her fiancé, Thomas O’Donnell, decorate their apartment in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx to match the season.
lead_paragraph: IF Elizabeth Khinda, a 28-year-old algebra teacher, had her way, she would live in a world of pink ruffles and floral-patterned pastels, a place as frilly and feminine as the inside of a jewelry box. ''When we buy a house,'' said Ms. Khinda, who is engaged to Thomas O'Donnell, 32, a telecommunications worker, ''I'd like to have a very girlie room with a vanity and a very feminine chair and lots of pinks and florals.''
abstract: Habitats column on Elizabeth Khinda and Thomas O'Donnell, engaged couple sharing apartment in Woodlawn section of Bronx; living room offers sweeping views and Khinda fine-tunes colors and decor throughout year, using vivid seasonal changes of park as inspiration; photos (M)
headline: Don't Like the Décor? Wait a Minute

snippet: Changing party affiliation is no guarantee of survival. Just ask ex-Representative Michael P. Forbes.
lead_paragraph: Periods of intense partisanship and turmoil occasionally lead to a smattering of Congressional party-switching. But changing affiliation is no guarantee of political survival. Just ask ex-Representative Michael P. Forbes of New York. Before the recent decision by Representative Parker Griffith of Alabama to change his Congressional jersey, Mr. Forbes had been the last House member to abandon the majority for the minority. But back in 1999, Mr. Forbes, a three-term lawmaker, went the opposite direction of Mr. Griffith, sliding from the Republican column to the smaller Democratic side, saying his party had become too narrow and intolerant.
abstract: Alabama Democrat Rep Parker Griffith is first House member to switch to minority party from majority since 1999; path he has chosen is not without risks; about one-third of United States representatives who switched parties since 1980 have lost next election for their House seat or other office, while other have become influential and admired members of their new party; photo (M)
headline: The Time May Be Ripe for Party-Switching, but Its Risks Are Apparent

snippet: A growing number of graduate programs in sustainability address the issues affecting cities.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Andrew Pattison was looking to pursue a graduate degree in sustainability, he drew on his post-college experience working as a conservation biologist in upstate New York. Butterflies were his thing, and he produced numerous recommendations about what should be done to protect them. ''I found that quote-unquote important people who were decision makers would read the reports I filed and then not follow them,'' Mr. Pattison says. Those frustrations led him in a different direction. ''I knew I wanted to study the way decisions were made on environmental policy,'' he says. He also knew where many of the important decisions were made: in cities. With energy and climate policy, he says, ''the problem is global, but all politics are local.''
headline: Sustainability Comes of Age

snippet: As early as 9,000 years ago, inhabitants of a Neolithic village in China were brewing a type of mead with an alcohol content of 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: Maybe they were better off in the Stone Age than we think. As early as 9,000 years ago, long before the wheel was invented, inhabitants of a Neolithic village in China were brewing a type of mead, or fermented honey and fruit, with an alcohol content of 10 percent, the archaeologist Patrick McGovern discovered recently. The finding by Dr. McGovern, a biomolecular archaeologist at the University of Pennsylvania Museum, fits in with his thesis that the development of agriculture was the result of an irrepressible impulse toward drinking and intoxication, Spiegel Online reports. ''Consuming high energy sugar and alcohol was a fabulous solution for surviving in a hostile environment with few natural resources,'' said Dr. McGovern, a leading expert on ancient brewing.
abstract: Archaeologist Patrick McGovern has discovered that inhabitants of Neolithic village in China were brewing beverage with 10 percent alcohol content; finding supports his thesis that development of agriculture was result of impulse toward intoxication (S)
headline: The Stone Age Rocked, if You Liked Your Liquor
byline: {"organization"=>"THE NEW YORK TIMES", "original"=>"By THE NEW YORK TIMES", "person"=>[]}

snippet: An attack that followed years of threats to kill a Danish cartoonist appeared to have come close to succeeding.
lead_paragraph: A heavily bandaged 28-year-old Somali man was wheeled into a Danish court on a stretcher on Saturday and was charged with attempting to kill a Danish artist whose 2005 cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad was one of a series that ignited riots across the Muslim world, as well as firebombing attacks on Danish and other Western diplomatic missions. At one point during the attack, which took place late Friday, only a reinforced bathroom door protected the artist, Kurt Westergaard, 74, who was shielding his 5-year-old granddaughter as the attacker -- armed with an ax and a knife and shouting ''Revenge!'' and ''Blood!'' -- tried to smash through the door, according to an account the artist gave to the newspaper that employs him, Jyllands-Posten.
abstract: Somali man, whose name is not released is charged with attempting to kill Danish artist Kurt Westergaard, whose 2005 cartoon of Prophet Muhammad was one of series published in newspaper Jyllands-Posten that sparked riots across Muslim world; Danes had hoped anger over cartoons had begun to die down; public shock over attack is balanced by relief that system established by country's security agencies to protect Westergaard worked; photos (M)
headline: Cartoonist In Denmark Calls Attack 'Really Close'

snippet: On the corner of Western and Devon Avenues, many of the approximately 200,000 Chicagoans of Indian and Pakistani descent live side by side.
lead_paragraph: Abdul Kagdi looked up from his Koran with a stare as frigid as the winter breeze swirling outside his 110-220 Volts Electronics shop. ''I only have a few minutes,'' he said, his courtesy overcoming his irritation at being interrupted. ''I'm praying.'' Mr. Kagdi's shop is located at one of Chicago's more unusual street corners. Neighbors who inhabit the red and yellow brick walk-up apartments that surround the store come largely from an area of the world that fights over the Kashmir Valley, which lies in the middle of the rivalry between India and Pakistan and where people of different religions attack and kill one another.
headline: Shedding Old Rivalries And Pulling Together

snippet: SPIEGEL--Herbert MD, (June 29, 1914 - December 15, 2009) internationally renowned psychiatrist practicing in New York City, Battalion Surgeon, North Africa, WWII, awarded Purple Heart, teacher of Military Psychiatry, Professor and Special Lecturer at...
lead_paragraph: SPIEGEL--Herbert MD, (June 29, 1914 - December 15, 2009) internationally renowned psychiatrist practicing in New York City, Battalion Surgeon, North Africa, WWII, awarded Purple Heart, teacher of Military Psychiatry, Professor and Special Lecturer at Psychiatric Institute, Columbia University Medical Center and named A Living Treasure for his pioneer work as a clinician, teacher, author and researcher in hypnosis and brief psychotherapy. He is survived by his wife and colleague, Dr. Marcia Greenleaf, his son Dr. David Spiegel, his daughter Dr. Ann Spiegel, their spouses, four grandchildren and extended family. His profound contributions to Psychotherapy will live on through those he taught and those whose lives he touched so deeply.

snippet: By the end of the decade “indie-rock” has become an ever-expanding, incomprehensibly cluttered taxonomy of subgenres.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago Hipster Runoff, a blog that ridicules bohemian culture with hilarious precision, began advertising a ''genre shirt.'' In photos that seem straight out of an American Apparel billboard, a young woman poses in the T-shirt, which asks, ''What kind of music do u listen 2?'' and offers, in a matrix of small type, more than 200 underground musical styles, both real (shoegaze, crab-core) and fake (Sufjan-house, crab-gaze). For those who has scratched their heads in confusion (or rolled their eyes) reading a music blog lately, the joke is uncomfortably close to the truth. Ten or 20 years ago it was relatively easy to define the term ''indie-rock'' as a handful of related styles and a collective audience slightly on the fringe of the mainstream. But by the end of the decade it has become an ever-expanding, incomprehensibly cluttered taxonomy of subgenres. So you say you like indie-rock -- well, do you mean mumblecore? Freak-folk? Ambient doom-metal? Eight-bit?
abstract: Article on indie-rock genres; says by end of last decade, they became incomprehensibly cluttered sub-genres, which has actually been good for music; decline of major labels and MTV's reduced music coverage noted; photos (M)
headline: When Indie-Rock Genres Outnumber the Bands

snippet: Readers inquire about illegal DVDs, and safety on the streets and on the subways in New York.
lead_paragraph: Q.I am tempted by movie DVDs being sold cheaply on the street, but I'd still like to be honest. Is there any way to tell if a DVD has been pirated just by looking at it? A. Here are some telltale signs from Elizabeth Kaltman, a spokeswoman for the Motion Picture Association of America: loose cellophane packaging, poorly reproduced labeling, lack of holographic labeling, cut-rate pricing, or sales made by street vendors out of a box, backpack or blanket on the sidewalk.

snippet: Social networking is responsible for the dumbing-down of American trash talk. Chad Ochocinco used this week's matchup with the All-Pro cornerback Darrelle Revis as reason to compose a Twitter ''Song of Myself,'' but Ochocinco's barbaric yawp lacked...
lead_paragraph: Social networking is responsible for the dumbing-down of American trash talk. Chad Ochocinco used this week's matchup with the All-Pro cornerback Darrelle Revis as reason to compose a Twitter ''Song of Myself,'' but Ochocinco's barbaric yawp lacked its usual flair. ''I'm coming to the big apple to give NY what they've never seen, an escape inmate gone wild on Revis Island'' is well composed, but it doesn't resonate like an end-zone ''Riverdance.'' Ochocinco contains multitudes, so even he was moved to compliment Revis. ''Technique is awesome -- good patience at the line'' was among the few printable scouting reports. Revis was mostly silent, as one who can't get a word in edgewise often is. The Revis-Ochocinco battle will end in a stalemate, turning the Bengals' passing game into a series of 5-yard dump-offs to Brian Leonard. The Jets' passing game (what's left of it) will be shut down by Leon Hall, Johnathan Joseph and the solid Bengals secondary. That leaves both teams trying to run against great run defenses. The Bengals and the Jets use more formations with six offensive linemen than other teams, so don't expect a lot of finesse. It's a good thing Giants Stadium is closing, because with two teams running up the middle behind wide-load offensive fronts, the playing surface may be permanently warped after Sunday night.
abstract: Matchup between New York Giants and Minnesota Vikings discussed (S)
headline: Trading Talk for Tweets As Jets and Bengals Face Off

snippet: PARKINS--Leroy "Sam", 83, of Manhattan, died November 19, 2009 in Tel Aviv. Musician extraordinaire-jazz clarinet/sax, composer, record producer, Columbia, RCA. Beloved husband of 41 years of the late Camilla Kemple. He is survived by siblings Ted...
lead_paragraph: PARKINS--Leroy "Sam", 83, of Manhattan, died November 19, 2009 in Tel Aviv. Musician extraordinaire-jazz clarinet/sax, composer, record producer, Columbia, RCA. Beloved husband of 41 years of the late Camilla Kemple. He is survived by siblings Ted Parkins, Rosemary Monroe; nephews Ted Parkins, Jr., Michael Monroe; nieces Jean Monroe, Jennifer McKinnon; beloved "honorary daughter" Joan Falk; and countless bereft friends. Commemoration February 7, 2010.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKINS, LEROY "SAM"

snippet: Two of Chicago’s most prominent reform politicians gave their blessings to candidates last week. The beneficiaries better hope it is not an omen.

Paul Vallas, the former Chicago public schools chief executive -- whose narrow loss to Rod R. Blagojevich in the 2002 Democratic primary for governor has made him a favorite ''I told you so'' lesson of the good-government crowd -- endorsed David Hoffman, a Democrat, for the United States Senate on Wednesday.

snippet: As early as 9,000 years ago, inhabitants of a Neolithic village in China were brewing a type of mead with an alcohol content of 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: Maybe they were better off in the Stone Age than we think. As early as 9,000 years ago, long before the wheel was invented, inhabitants of a Neolithic village in China were brewing a type of mead, or fermented honey and fruit, with an alcohol content of 10 percent, the archaeologist Patrick McGovern discovered recently. The finding by Dr. McGovern, a biomolecular archaeologist at the University of Pennsylvania Museum, fits in with his thesis that the development of agriculture was the result of an irrepressible impulse toward drinking and intoxication, Spiegel Online reports. ''Consuming high energy sugar and alcohol was a fabulous solution for surviving in a hostile environment with few natural resources,'' said Dr. McGovern, a leading expert on ancient brewing.
abstract: Archaeologist Patrick McGovern has discovered that inhabitants of Neolithic village in China were brewing beverage with 10 percent alcohol content; finding supports his thesis that development of agriculture was result of impulse toward intoxication (S)
headline: The Stone Age Rocked, if You Liked Your Liquor
byline: {"organization"=>"THE NEW YORK TIMES", "original"=>"By THE NEW YORK TIMES", "person"=>[]}

snippet: Asian carp, the voracious, nonnative fish whose arrival near Lake Michigan is threatening to cause havoc in the Great Lakes, are now setting off strife on land as well.     In an urgent effort to close down Chicago-area passages that could allow the...
lead_paragraph: Asian carp, the voracious, nonnative fish whose arrival near Lake Michigan is threatening to cause havoc in the Great Lakes, are now setting off strife on land as well. In an urgent effort to close down Chicago-area passages that could allow the unwanted fish to reach Lake Michigan, the State of Michigan is suing the State of Illinois and other entities that govern the waterways here. Minnesota, Ohio and Wisconsin have filed documents in recent days supporting Michigan's move, and Indiana says it will soon do the same.
abstract: State of Michigan is suing Illinois and other entities governing waterways in effort to close down Chicago-area passages that could allow invasive Asian carp to spread into Great Lakes; suit is supported by Minnesota, Ohio and Wisconsin, and Indiana is expected to join them; rift could damage larger cooperation on lakes; map; photo (M)
headline: Fight Against an Invasive Fish Threatens a Fragile Unity in the Great Lakes

snippet: No federal law prohibits illegal immigrants from attending college in the United States, but illegal students still face numerous barriers to higher education.
lead_paragraph: NO federal law prohibits illegal immigrants from attending college in the United States, or requires them to disclose their situation. Most colleges don't even check immigration status when students apply for financial aid -- only 31 percent, according to a survey last year by the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers.
headline: Whither the Dream

snippet: Kitchen Zinc serves what is billed as artisanal pizza: thin-crust pies topped with local ingredients. Just don’t go looking for the usual red sauce and mozzarella version.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN has a reputation as a Mecca for pizza lovers, with Wooster Street eateries like Sally's and Frank Pepe serving pies with cracker-thin crusts since the early 1900s. But the abundance and pedigree of pie-serving places didn't stop Donna Curran and the chef Denise Appel, owners of Zinc Restaurant on Chapel Street, from opening their own in June. Kitchen Zinc, on the sight of their erstwhile Asian outpost, Chow, serves what is billed as artisanal pizza: thin-crust pies topped with local ingredients. They cost somewhat more than the typical New Haven pizza -- and are often worth it -- but don't go looking for the usual red sauce and mozzarella.
headline: In a Pizza Mecca, A Nontraditional Take

snippet: After traveling far and wide, and studying at rabbinical school, Cary Rosenzweig became chief executive of IMVU, a virtual community.
lead_paragraph: THREE of my four grandparents immigrated to America from Russia, through Ellis Island, in the early 1920s. My father grew up in Brooklyn, and my mother in Buffalo. I was born in Syracuse, where my father was in medical school. After he graduated, he was drafted into the Air Force, which assigned him first to San Francisco, then to Madrid, where we lived for three years. When I was 9, my parents decided to settle in the suburbs south of San Francisco. Later, I went to Stanford, where I studied international relations. In college, I began to get involved in Jewish activities and that's how I met Laura, my wife.
abstract: IMVU Inc chief executive Cary Rosenzweig The Boss column discusses his career; photo; chart (M)
headline: Frontiers, Virtual and Real

lead_paragraph: The Right Hand of the Fathers It is clear to me on reading David D. Kirkpatrick's article that Robert P. George has hijacked the word ''reason'' to suit the beliefs and purposes of the group of Catholic bishops who espouse his philosophical dogma. Recognizing reality is a better guide toward truth. As Louis Pasteur once said, ''The greatest derangement of the mind is to believe in something because one wishes it to be so.''

snippet: What might knit us together in 2010? Prominent New Yorkers muse aloud on some collective goals for the city.
lead_paragraph: THE making of New Year's resolutions is, at once, the most optimistic and cynical of acts. The vow to change posits a continuing faith in human improvement (''I'll lose 30 pounds this year''), but the format, a checkable mental list, is so tyrannical and skeptical of success that it often leads to failure (''Yeah, well, maybe 20.'') Whether it's the nagging housewives and jealous husbands counseled by an 1880 New York Times editorial to ''foreswear all such works of the evil one'' or a latter-day smoker vowing to be done with a pack-a-day habit, there seems to be a biological imperative to seek excellence each Jan. 1 but a genetic incapacity to obtain it. What better metaphor, then, for New York City, a metropolis forever chasing progress and perfection but perhaps best at making do with the reality of considerably less?
headline: New York's Resolutions

snippet: California running back Jahvid Best said he would skip his senior year and enter the N.F.L. draft. Best entered the season as a leading contender for the Heisman Trophy, but he missed the final four games of the season with injuries.            Jets...
lead_paragraph: California running back Jahvid Best said he would skip his senior year and enter the N.F.L. draft. Best entered the season as a leading contender for the Heisman Trophy, but he missed the final four games of the season with injuries. Jets punter Steve Weatherford said his injured right hamstring was ''feeling better,'' but he still had some tightness a day before the team's game Sunday against Cincinnati.
headline: California's Best To Enter Draft

snippet: On the corner of Western and Devon Avenues, many of the approximately 200,000 Chicagoans of Indian and Pakistani descent live side by side.
lead_paragraph: Abdul Kagdi looked up from his Koran with a stare as frigid as the winter breeze swirling outside his 110-220 Volts Electronics shop. ''I only have a few minutes,'' he said, his courtesy overcoming his irritation at being interrupted. ''I'm praying.'' Mr. Kagdi's shop is located at one of Chicago's more unusual street corners. Neighbors who inhabit the red and yellow brick walk-up apartments that surround the store come largely from an area of the world that fights over the Kashmir Valley, which lies in the middle of the rivalry between India and Pakistan and where people of different religions attack and kill one another.
headline: Shedding Old Rivalries And Pulling Together

snippet: SPIEGEL--Herbert MD, (June 29, 1914 - December 15, 2009) internationally renowned psychiatrist practicing in New York City, Battalion Surgeon, North Africa, WWII, awarded Purple Heart, teacher of Military Psychiatry, Professor and Special Lecturer at...
lead_paragraph: SPIEGEL--Herbert MD, (June 29, 1914 - December 15, 2009) internationally renowned psychiatrist practicing in New York City, Battalion Surgeon, North Africa, WWII, awarded Purple Heart, teacher of Military Psychiatry, Professor and Special Lecturer at Psychiatric Institute, Columbia University Medical Center and named A Living Treasure for his pioneer work as a clinician, teacher, author and researcher in hypnosis and brief psychotherapy. He is survived by his wife and colleague, Dr. Marcia Greenleaf, his son Dr. David Spiegel, his daughter Dr. Ann Spiegel, their spouses, four grandchildren and extended family. His profound contributions to Psychotherapy will live on through those he taught and those whose lives he touched so deeply.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, HERBERT MD

The Jets' passing game (what's left of it) will be shut down by Leon Hall, Johnathan Joseph and the solid Bengals secondary. That leaves both teams trying to run against great run defenses. The Bengals and the Jets use more formations with six offensive linemen than other teams, so don't expect a lot of finesse. snippet: Social media sites are among the most visited on the Internet, and schools are developing fuller curriculums in the area.
lead_paragraph: THE announcement last year that Birmingham City University in central England would offer a master's in social networking attracted international coverage -- and comment, appropriately on Twitter and Mashable, on the nature of Facebook and My-Space as academic discipline. Jon Hickman, a Birmingham lecturer, defended the program's rigor in an e-mail message: ''This semester, we have been exploring business models, and considering social media as a cultural activity.''

snippet: Cases where ethics guidelines are not followed by freelancers occur with dismaying frequency.
lead_paragraph: Mary Tripsas, an associate professor at the Harvard Business School, has been writing a monthly column in The Times called ''Prototype,'' about corporate innovation, her academic specialty. Last Sunday, she highlighted the 3M Company's customer innovation center at its headquarters in St. Paul. Today, an editor's note in the paper says that, had The Times known that 3M paid Tripsas' expenses to Minnesota in November, the column would not have been published as it was written. Tripsas violated a policy against accepting travel or anything else of value from the subjects of coverage. She will no longer be writing for The Times.
abstract: Clark Hoyt Public Editor column cites instances of freelancers with conflicts of interest writing for New York Times; suggests Times editors take false comfort in elaborate system and paperwork associated with retaining freelancers, when in fact they should have better communication with freelancers to assure that such conflicts do not exist or, if they do, to terminate relationship (M)
headline: Times Standards, Staffers or Not

snippet: So you’re drowning in a sea of information. Perhaps the answer is more information.
lead_paragraph: I can remember when I first thought seriously about Twitter. Last March, I was at the SXSW conference, a conclave in Austin, Tex., where technology, media and music are mashed up and re-imagined, and, not so coincidentally, where Twitter first rolled out in 2007. As someone who was oversubscribed on Facebook, overwhelmed by the computer-generated RSS feeds of news that came flying at me, and swamped by incoming e-mail messages, the last thing I wanted was one more Web-borne intrusion into my life. And then there was the name. Twitter.
abstract: History of Internet shows that some Web sites go in and out of fashion, while others endure and become essential tools; many observers were initially dismissive of Twitter, but it appears that it will become standard form of communication and networking; most frequent objection is sharing of minutiae of people's lives, although that is increasingly being seen as helping to define what is important; drawing (M)
headline: Why Twitter Will Endure

snippet: <!-- ANTONINA S GLASS -->GLASS--Antonina S., 99, widow of George B. Jerzy Glass, MD, died peacefully at home surrounded by family on December 31, 2009, after a brief, final illness. A survivor of World War II, she, along with her husband and young...
lead_paragraph: GLASS--Antonina S., 99, widow of George B. Jerzy Glass, MD, died peacefully at home surrounded by family on December 31, 2009, after a brief, final illness. A survivor of World War II, she, along with her husband and young son, came to New York in 1945 to start a new life and lived there to the present. She is survived by her son, Andrew Glass, MD, of Portland, OR; by her daughter, Janet Alteveer, MD, of Moorestown, NJ; son-in-law Robert and daughter-in-law Nancy; nine grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren, and family around the world. She received Poland's Knight's Cross in 1996 for her extensive chartable work for blind children. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, on Monday, 7-9pm. Service on Tuesday at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Doctors Without Borders would be appreciated.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, ANTONINA S.

snippet: OWEN--Melvin M., D.D.S., dentist, inventor, writer, artist - passed...
lead_paragraph: OWEN--Melvin M., D.D.S., dentist, inventor, writer, artist - passed away quietly on Wednesday, December 23, 2009, in Georgetown, Texas. He was an outstanding dental practitioner in New York City and Ft. Myers, Florida. Mel learned the importance of painless dentistry from his father and excelled at treating complex and difficult cases. In his efforts to always explore new techniques, he invented a diamond tool that substantially lessened the time preparing teeth for crowns and bridges. Mel's creative genius played out in many other avenues. He wrote stage scripts for numerous musical shows, designed furniture and fixtures, created amazing mobiles, sculptures and metal works, and crafted pottery, where he developed unique glazing techniques. He was among the first to help the blind study textbooks through audio tapes by establishing groups of volunteers to record them. Mel designed "flip books" to help teach activities such as a golf swing and developed a forerunner of today's more advanced golf simulators. Mel was dedicated to the spirit and mission of Rotary International, having been a member at clubs in Ft. Myers and Sun City for many years. He was active in a variety of groups at Sun City Georgetown, including the Sun City Theater Group, the Computer Club, the Solos Club, and the Creative Crafts and Clay Club. Over his lifetime, Mel was active as a tennis player, golfer, snow skier, sailor, boatman, windsurfer, bocce player, and bridge player. He loved to dance with his beautiful wife, Moana Holt Owen. Mel's zest for life encompassed many disciplines. His elegance and refinement lent an air of grace to every event. He could regale partygoers with tales of worldwide travels while charming his partners on the dance floor. Mel was always a gentleman without ceasing to be a gentle man, one whose kindness will be fondly remembered. The true testament to Mel is the warmth and love which he inspired in the hearts of the many fortunate enough to have known him throughout his rich and rewarding life. Mel was born in Brooklyn, NY, on August 13, 1923. After graduating from Erasmus Hall High School, Long Island University, and NYU Dental School, Mel served as an Army dentist in Alaska from 1946-47. He moved with Moana to Cape Coral, Florida, in 1975. After she passed on, he relocated to Sun City Georgetown in 1996. He leaves behind a lifetime treasure of loving memories for his son Mallard Owen and wife Judith Smith of Ashburn, Virginia; his daughter Meredith Owen of Round Rock, Texas; his sister, Alese Owen Pechter; his brother and sister-in-law, Edwin and Nancy Owen; and his nephews, John and Andrew Owen; and Stuart, Richard, Jay and Todd Pechter.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, MELVIN

snippet: Kanye West’s resistance to stasis has been his one constant in the last decade, which has taken him from behind-the-scenes Chicago rap-purist producer to perma-spotlighted global pop dynamo.
lead_paragraph: JUST before Christmas, Kanye West interrupted a Los Angeles show by his protégé Kid Cudi to share some feelings with the crowd. ''This is my first time back in America for the past, like, three, four months,'' he said. Since his pillorying for divebombing Taylor Swift's acceptance speech at the MTV Video Music Awards in September, he'd been uncharacteristically mute, head tucked underneath shell, waiting for the darts to stop.
abstract: Article profiles Chicago rap producer turned global pop dynamo Kanye West; huge success over past decade and uncertainty about himself discussed; photos (L)
headline: Creativity and Chaos, Served in Equal Measure

snippet: It is a New Year’s Eve tradition in many parts of Latin America to ring in the new year wearing new underwear — and the color signifies one’s resolution for the year ahead.
lead_paragraph: From the flurry of New Year's Eve sales at some market stalls in Mexico City, one might wonder if those living south of the border are going through tough economic times at all. They are, reports the Economix blog of The New York Times. Just look at what they have been buying. It is a New Year's Eve tradition in many parts of Latin America to ring in the new year wearing new underwear. There's more: The color of the underwear signifies what resolution one is seeking for the year ahead. Red means love. Yellow means money.
abstract: Markets in Mexico report uptick in sales of yellow underwear; nation's tradition calls for ringing in New Year with new underwear and color yellow signifies money, suggesting people are hoping for better year financially (S)
headline: Red or Yellow? South of the Border, Underwear Says All

snippet: BLACKER--Virginia Ann, age 64, passed away on December 28th, her 41st wedding anniversary, after bravely battling pulmonary fibrosis for over two years. Ginny was the loving, caring, best friend, cheerful, kind and wonderful wife of Stephen Blacker....
lead_paragraph: BLACKER--Virginia Ann, age 64, passed away on December 28th, her 41st wedding anniversary, after bravely battling pulmonary fibrosis for over two years. Ginny was the loving, caring, best friend, cheerful, kind and wonderful wife of Stephen Blacker. She was also the best mom, mentor and confidante of sons Peter Blacker (Luis Gonzalez) and Andrew Blacker (Elizabeth Sarachek Blacker). She was the adoring grandmother of Braden Storm Blacker, whom he fondly called "Gigi". Ginny was devoted to her sisters ("the Kelly Girls") and brothers-in-law: Susie and Bill Untereker and Meg and Kenny Rehders. She was also the loving and caring aunt of seven nephews and nieces. Ginny was a woman of great style, intellectual curiosity and limitless laughter. She truly loved life, family and her many interests. Ginny was the consummate--and constant--hostess. She was a fabulous, creative cook whose generous hospitality will always be remembered by her many friends. Ginny traveled all over the world with her husband--each trip delighting her more than the last. At home, she was an avid reader and was actively involved in doing good for others. She helped launch the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center and serving as a Gala Chair for Family Counseling Services. Ginny's sense of humor, positive spirit and sense of humanity were an inspiration for all who knew her. Her family and her friends were her life. She made us laugh and taught us that being selfless was the key to true happiness. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Association. http://www.pulmonary fibrosis.org/gifts.htm. 312.587.9272
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKER, VIRGINIA ANN

snippet: The Preservation Hall Jazz Band has recruited younger players and broadened its repertoire, but its roots remain in traditional New Orleans music.
lead_paragraph: THE Preservation Hall Jazz Band, which in its 48 years has built a global reputation for presenting the traditional New Orleans sound, is taking a more contemporary approach these days -- recruiting younger players, expanding its repertoire and allowing surrealist elements to creep into its performances. But even as it modernizes its approach, the band, which comes to the Tarrytown Music Hall on Thursday, is keeping the old-time faith -- hiring musicians whose strong links to the pioneers of jazz assure the music's authenticity.
headline: New Orleans Jazz Band Gets in Step With the Times

snippet: Fear of terrorism can kill the impulse to get on a plane and see the world. No one has tallied the adventures not dared since 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that flying in a plane is potentially dangerous -- just as everyone knows that climbing Mount Everest is dangerous. What goes up must come down; and if you put yourself at a great height, you put yourself at risk of falling, though the odds of perishing in a plane crash are one in ten million, whereas for every ten Everest climbers who reach the peak, one dies ... a far less comfortable margin. One reason that airports have bars, and that flight attendants ply passengers with beer, wine and cocktails, is that flight industry higher-ups are well aware that a drink or two can calm the nerves of timorous fliers, and that indeed most of their customers fear air travel to some degree. If you doubt the truth of this, take a look at your seatmates the next time a plane you're on hits an air pocket and drops before righting itself. You'll see your fellow passengers (some of them, anyhow) praying -- hoping divine intervention will keep the magical container aloft. Regina Spektor wove this thought into her album, ''Far'' last June, in the song ''Laughing With,'' which goes, ''No one laughs at God when their airplane starts to uncontrollably shake.'' It's the 21st century, but that doesn't keep flying from remaining, on one level, an act of faith.
abstract: Many people have innate fear of flying, and that fear has been compounded in last decade by acts of terrorism; while terror incidents barely register statistically, they cause public to panic and feel vulnerable; in wake of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab's attempted sabotage, government and air traffic officials are scrambling to reassure citizenry about safety of air travel; photo (M)
headline: The Price of High Anxiety

snippet: The ailing Bears are still run by committee and Virginia Halas McCaskey, 85-year-old owner, is committee chairman who must approve every major decision.
lead_paragraph: As the 85-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears franchise her father founded 90 years ago, Virginia Halas McCaskey knows National Football League history is once again in her hands. Coach Lovie Smith, General Manager Jerry Angelo and even Ted Phillips, the team president, have faced mounting criticism as the team struggled through another disappointing season. Who stays or goes -- according to those close to the Bears organization last week -- is ultimately up to Mrs. McCaskey. She would probably rather spend Sunday disguised as Staley, the team's mascot.
headline: Coach's Future Is in the Hands of Mama Bear

snippet: At the beginning of winter, mild days seem like just a way of clearing the canvas, before a snowstorm puts down a fresh ground of white.
lead_paragraph: Last week felt like a last chance before winter. The snow melted, dying back until the vole trails became thin green paths through the remains of whiteness. The ice unbound itself from the rim of the horse tanks. One warm morning, a bat fluttered past my head, resting on the clapboards for a moment and then arcing around to the east side of the house. Despite the sense of relenting, the ground was still frozen solid. And then it began to snow again -- light, voluminous snow, swelling in the air and muffling every detail. Watching it, I felt a sense of intention in the weather, as if those mild days were just a way of clearing the canvas, scraping away the old paint, before laying down a fresh ground of white.
abstract: Verlyn Klinkenborg Rural Life column suggests light snow that is falling is harbinger of impending winter (M)
headline: Snowing Forward

snippet: The snowboarder Kevin Pearce remained in intensive care, in critical but stable condition, at a Salt Lake City hospital two days after sustaining a severe head injury while training in the halfpipe at Park City Mountain Resort in Utah.      Dr. Holly...
lead_paragraph: The snowboarder Kevin Pearce remained in intensive care, in critical but stable condition, at a Salt Lake City hospital two days after sustaining a severe head injury while training in the halfpipe at Park City Mountain Resort in Utah. Dr. Holly Ledyard of the University of Utah hospital said in a statement that Pearce had a ''severe traumatic brain injury.'' She added: ''He is intubated and being kept sedated. The focus over the next week will be watching for any swelling in his brain and keeping his brain pressure normal. Kevin has a long recovery ahead of him.''
abstract: Olympic hopeful Kevin Pearce, US¼
headline: Snowboarder Is Facing Long Recovery

snippet: The General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church has tried something new to raise cash: an apartment building called the Chelsea Enclave has gone up on its grounds.
lead_paragraph: IN the middle of Chelsea, an area known historically for artists and more recently for luxury condominiums, there is something unexpected: an active theological seminary that's been in the neighborhood since the 1820s. Recently, the General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church has taken a cue from its surroundings in the interest of raising cash: an apartment building called the Chelsea Enclave has gone up on its grounds. It is scheduled for completion next month.
abstract: Chelsea Enclave apartments is luxury condop building in heart of Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood, on grounds of General Theological Seminary, active seminary run by Episcopal Church; 53-unit building offers apartments from $1.325 million to $10.75 million; building's exterior was subject to approval by Landmarks Preservation Commission; photos (M)
headline: A Fraternal Twin For a Seminary

snippet: Students are increasingly focused on how their major will translate into a job. The response to that demand is changing higher education.
lead_paragraph: THOMAS COLLEGE, a liberal arts school in Maine, advertises itself as Home of the Guaranteed Job! Students who can't find work in their fields within six months of graduation can come back to take classes free, or have the college pay their student loans for a year. The University of Louisiana, Lafayette, is eliminating its philosophy major, while Michigan State University is doing away with American studies and classics, after years of declining enrollments in those majors.
abstract: Students and parents are increasingly concerned about how their majors will translate into career; colleges are rushing to prove their relevance but worry students may be so intent on picking right major, they will not allow time for self-discovery; while shift in attitudes is reflected in changing curriculums, education experts are wary of training students too narrowly; say employers still value good writing and speaking skills (M)
headline: Making College 'Relevant'

snippet: Devin Scott’s goal was to waste as little time as possible getting to and from his office in the Flatiron district.
lead_paragraph: A LOCATION near work was essential for Devin Scott. The goal was to waste as little time as possible getting to and from his office in the Flatiron district. His old rental, in fact, was just a block away. So when he decided to buy a place, he confined his apartment hunt to the Flatiron district and Kips Bay, hoping to remain within just a few blocks. He would either walk or take the subway, whichever proved faster.
abstract: The Hunt column on search by Devin Scott for one-bedroom apartment within walking distance of office in Flatiron District of Manhattan for under $500,000; found one-bedroom condominium unit on Madison Avenue near East 27th Street for $439,000; photos (M)
headline: It's O.K. to Hit the Snooze Button

snippet: Katie Roiphe has a long history of taking on complicated, fraught topics, and her essay in this issue is no exception.
lead_paragraph: Katie Roiphe has a long history of taking on complicated, fraught topics, and her cover essay in this issue is no exception. ''It was inspired by the vitriolic response to the sex scenes in Philip Roth's latest book, both in reviews and dinner party conversations,'' she said in a recent e-mail message. ''I always think an excessively rageful response to a book warrants a closer look: exactly what is he challenging, and why does it make us so furious?'' ''I have always been fascinated by the fashionable language of sexual intimacy and what it reveals about the larger culture,'' she added. ''Whether in my first book on campus feminism in the early '90s or my latest book on unusual marriages in England in the 1920s, that's the theme that has obsessed me.''
abstract: Book Review editors introduce Katie Roiphe article on sex scenes by male novelists; drawing (S)
headline: Up Front

Or are they simply the latest editions of the books produced by publishers like Random House?

snippet: Kenneth Feinberg, Washington’s pay czar, has grappled more than anyone with the question of how much to pay executives at failed companies.
lead_paragraph: Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth Feinberg, the government's special master for executive compensation, and they were awaiting submissions from companies that had received (and not yet paid back) billions in what federal regulations call ''exceptional assistance'' from the government's Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP. The government had the authority to set compensation levels at those seven TARP recipients, and this was the companies' opportunity to plead for salaries and bonuses for each of its top 25 executives. Chrysler Financial and General Motors submitted their proposals -- about 2,000-plus pages each -- a few days before. Now, like college kids crashing a term paper, the other five -- A.I.G., Bank of America, Chrysler, Citigroup and General Motors Acceptance Corporation -- were frantically trying to get their pitches into Treasury's digital in-box by the Aug. 14 deadline.
headline: What's a Bailed-Out Banker Worth?

snippet: Instead of just focusing on casinos, the Shinnecock tribe could find other ways to leverage its valuable real estate.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 years late -- 31 if you count from the tribe's petition -- the federal government has acknowledged that the Shinnecocks of Southampton, Long Island, are an Indian tribe. Settling that question raises new ones. The Shinnecocks will almost certainly try to build a casino -- they have been lobbying as hard for one as they have for recognition -- but how big, and where? The ''where'' is an especially interesting question. Casinos are usually built on reservation land. The Shinnecocks live on the East End of Long Island, a national depository of wealth, privilege and privacy. When the tribe jumped the gun a few years back and bulldozed part of its property for a bingo hall, the not-in-my-backyard opposition erupting from the dunes and privet hedges was ferocious. And that was just a skirmish.
abstract: Editorial urges Shinnecocks, newly recognized as tribe by Obama administration, to spend energies on something other than opening casinos; notes tribe's long, proud history along with geographic advantage and support for tribe by New York State officials, including Gov David Paterson
headline: The Shinnecocks, Recognized

snippet: The former Justice Department lawyer talks about Bush, Lincoln and the so-called torture memos.
lead_paragraph: Your new book, ''Crisis and Command,'' is an eloquent, fact-laden history of audacious power grabs by American presidents going back to George Washington. Which president would you say most violated laws enacted by Congress? I would say Lincoln. He sent the Army into offensive operations to try to stop the South from seceding. He didn't call Congress into special session until July 4, 1861, well after this had all happened. He basically acted on his own for three months.
abstract: Deborah Solomon interview with Bush administration Justice Department attorney John Yoo, who gained fame when he wrote so-called torture memos, which claimed Pres Bush could ignore certain laws and conventions prohibiting torture; photo (M)
headline: Power of Attorney

snippet: Are New Orleans hospitals liable for not protecting electrical generators? A series of lawsuits is testing the bounds of their liability.
lead_paragraph: Three years before Hurricane Katrina inundated New Orleans, a senior executive at Pendleton Memorial Methodist Hospital assessed its vulnerability to the sort of flooding that had been long feared there. His conclusion is now evidence in a lawsuit against Methodist that could have significant implications for hospitals nationwide.
headline: The New Katrina Flood

snippet: A trend toward specialization has crept into most fields over the past few decades, but few have embraced the shift more enthusiastically than graduate schools of business.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Adam Krueckeberg, 37, decided to leave his job as a vice president at Fidelity, the mutual fund giant, to return to school for an M.B.A., he didn't look at top-ranked schools like Harvard or the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, although his résumé was stellar and his scores strong. The only place that interested him was Boston College, the Jesuit-run institution that has been offering a dual M.B.A./M.S. in church management and pastoral ministry since 2005. ''I wanted a career that was more spiritually fulfilling,'' says Mr. Krueckeberg, who plans to work in a Catholic diocese or university when he graduates, in 2012. ''I wouldn't have been able to train for that in a more traditional setting.''
abstract: Graduate schools of business have embraced trend toward specialization since 1990, when Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business International, main accreditation board for business schools, changed guidelines to encourage innovative curriculums; specialized programs zero in on practical applications rather than theory; niche MBA programs attract students who know exactly to which industry they are headed; photo (M)
headline: The Business of Zeroing In

snippet: Let it be written that in the first decade of the second millennium a host of gods and goddesses descended on the mortal land of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: O COME, let us adore them. Let it be written that in the first decade of the second millennium a host of gods and goddesses descended on the mortal land of Broadway. Julia, Jude, Hugh, Denzel, Daniel the Elder, Daniel the Younger, Catherine, Katie and he who was called P. Diddy. For these deities, known to all the world from the writ of the tabloids, the people arrived in multitudes, among them heathens who had never set foot in a theater before. And so the Pharisees of Broadway rejoiced, for their coffers were full again and their other expenses were low.

snippet: The San Francisco Symphony’s new Project San Francisco will offer a pair of residency programs with the composer George Benjamin and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between the rock stars of classical music and the orchestras and audiences that interact with them can generally be characterized as a series of memorable one-night stands. When the Lang Langs, Joshua Bells and Renée Flemings of the world arrive in town for an evening or two, tickets fly, and standing ovations shake concert halls. But no sooner has the applause died down than the artists are on a plane to the next city. Lately, however, orchestras across the country have been looking for ways to deepen their relationships with top-tier musicians. Artist residencies, ranging from one week to two years, are now de rigueur. The baritone Thomas Hampson and the composer Magnus Lindberg have lengthy residencies with the New York Philharmonic; the Chicago Symphony recently announced the appointment of the Bay Area composer Mason Bates as a composer in residence; and last year the Los Angeles Philharmonic created the position of creative chair for another Bay Area composer, John Adams.
headline: Asking Stars Not Just to Play, but Also to Stay

snippet: Delicacy International Market has a decidedly Eastern European flavor, with an emphasis on mushrooms, pickled vegetables and cans of fish, and a deli counter.
lead_paragraph: Despite the best intentions, New Year's resolutions seldom last long. Faced with the enticements at Delicacy International Market, resolutions that involve eating less are likely to evaporate. At first glance, this tightly confined store looks like other urban groceries, with a selection of fresh produce -- apples, pears, pomegranates, peppers and whatnot -- by the entrance. But step up to the shelves of canned and jarred goods, and the complexion changes. The display has a decidedly Eastern European flavor, with an emphasis on several mushroom species (including king boletes, $12 for a 24-ounce jar), pickled vegetables and cans of fish (notably mackerel, herring and cod liver, from $2.29 to $4).
headline: A Taste of Eastern Europe

snippet: It’s not surprising that nearly $40 million in federal stimulus funds will be going to programs for battery and electric car education  many of them at the graduate level.
lead_paragraph: FOR all the excitement surrounding the development of electric vehicles, a fundamental limiting factor remains: storage. How, after all, does one coax more miles out of a fully electric vehicle without creating a battery so big, and so heavy, that it cripples the car? To the extent that the Obama administration has made answering that question a national priority, it's not surprising that nearly $40 million in federal stimulus funds for battery and electric car education -- much of it at the graduate level -- was announced in August.
abstract: Electric and hybrid vehicles are priority for Obama administration; few universities had master's programs specializing in development of next-generation transportation but with $2.4 billion in stimulus funds aimed at spurring manufacture and deployment of electric cars and advanced batteries, need for specialization has increased; seven of nine colleges that received federal funds are set to create or expand their graduate level degrees; universities in Michigan, ground zero in collapse of American auto industry, drew about 25 percent of education money; photo (M)
headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Start Your Engine Programs

snippet: PROMISES, PROMISES: I asked a bunch of writers who had best sellers in 2009 if they had made any reading-related New Year's resolutions. Some were willing to recklessly commit to new courses of literary action -- but only after I promised not to do a...
lead_paragraph: PROMISES, PROMISES: I asked a bunch of writers who had best sellers in 2009 if they had made any reading-related New Year's resolutions. Some were willing to recklessly commit to new courses of literary action -- but only after I promised not to do a follow-up report next year. Alexander McCall Smith (''The Lost Art of Gratitude''), inset, swears he's going to finish ''A Suitable Boy,'' Vikram Seth's 1,400-page novel: ''I've carried it around in my suitcase for years, taking it to four continents, paying excess baggage charges on it. It deserves more than to be a suitcase novel: I shall finish it. I shall. I shall.''
abstract: Jennifer Schuessler notes best sellers of particular interest; listing of best sellers; photo (M)
headline: Inside the List

snippet: The Vikings' dynamic pass rush starts with Jared Allen, who leads the conference with 13 1/2 sacks. But opponents the past four weeks have slowed Allen with double teams, often quick chip blocks by a tight end or a guard. David Diehl could not handle...
lead_paragraph: The Vikings' dynamic pass rush starts with Jared Allen, who leads the conference with 13 1/2 sacks. But opponents the past four weeks have slowed Allen with double teams, often quick chip blocks by a tight end or a guard. David Diehl could not handle Carolina's Julius Peppers last week, so the Giants will probably need to roll a blocker over to help, leaving somebody one-on-one with defensive tackle Kevin Williams or defensive end Ray Edwards. If the Giants can contain them, Eli Manning should pick apart the Vikings' secondary. NUMBER TO WATCH

snippet: Jimmy Van Bramer, newly elected to the New York City Council, takes over Eric N. Gioia’s office space in Woodside, Queens.
lead_paragraph: JIMMY VAN BRAMER, one of 13 new members elected in November to the New York City Council, lives a few blocks away from 47-01 Queens Boulevard in Woodside, where his predecessor, Eric N. Gioia, kept an office for the past eight years. Mr. Van Bramer, 40, a former Queens Borough Public Library official, decided to keep the place, Suite No. 203. Mr. Gioia left Mr. Van Bramer a welcome note in the drawer of the big desk, along with this advice: Lock the windows and doors. The office had been broken into twice (burglars, not political operatives). The first time, the computers were stolen, which was problematic, Mr. Gioia said, because as chairman of the Council's Oversight and Investigations Committee, he had some sensitive information on those hard drives. As a worker changed the locks, Mr. Van Bramer surveyed the clutter of desks, phone wires and supplies. Ah, the glamour of public office. He said he would modernize the dingy décor with a hasty repainting and recarpeting job, and update Mr. Gioia's poster of Mookie Wilson, a Mets center fielder in the 1980s, with one of himself standing with José Reyes, the team's current shortstop. MR. GIOIA opened the Queens Boulevard office, with its view of the elevated No. 7 train, on the day of his inauguration, Jan. 1, 2002, and instituted a firm policy for the Manhattancentric officials who wanted to see him. ''I wouldn't meet with them unless they came to Queens, to this office,'' he explained, adding that Hillary Rodham Clinton was among those who made the trek to Woodside. Mr. Gioia, 36, who ran unsuccessfully in the Democratic primary for public advocate, will now put his political prowess and connections to work as a bank executive. He took with him his beloved Mookie poster but left the leather couch where industrious aides would sometimes grab some sleep, the volumes of the New York City Charter on the bookshelf, an aging television with a slot for a VHS tape, and the old desk behind a partition -- it belonged to a particularly messy employee who was required to hide her desk. ''That's the great thing about public office,'' Mr. Gioia said, slapping his former office chair. ''All this stuff, even my office chair, it belongs to the people of the city of New York. And the next public servant who comes in will use it.''
abstract: New City Council member Jimmy Van Bramer and outgoing Councilman Eric Gioia comment on office in Woodside, Queens, that Van Bramer will occupy and Gioia will relinquish; photos (M)
headline: Chronicle of a Changing City

snippet: President Obama declared for the first time that a Yemeni branch of Al Qaeda sponsored the attempted Christmas Day plane bombing.
lead_paragraph: President Obama declared for the first time on Saturday that a branch of Al Qaeda based in Yemen sponsored the attempted Christmas Day bombing of an American passenger jet, and he vowed that those behind the failed attack ''will be held to account.'' In his first weekly Saturday address of the new year, Mr. Obama rebutted attacks by former Vice President Dick Cheney and other Republicans who since the episode have accused him of not recognizing that the struggle against terrorists is a war. Mr. Obama said he was well aware that ''our nation is at war against a far-reaching network of violence and hatred.''
abstract: Pres Obama declares for first time that Yemen-based branch of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula sponsored attempted Christmas Day airline bombing; vows those responsible for failed attack will be held accountable; comments suggest government has largely come to accept Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab's account of plot and group's claims; Republicans and former Vice Pres Cheney had accused Obama of not recognizing that United States is at war with terrorists (M)
headline: Obama Says Al Qaeda in Yemen Planned Bombing Plot, and He Vows Retribution

snippet: ELSKUS--Ann (nee Crewdson), 82, wife of renowned stained glass artist Albinas Elskus, passed away early Christmas eve at York hospital, Maine, after a brief hospital stay. Born in Lewistown, PA, she grew up in Nitro, WV, eloped with Albinas Elskus in...
lead_paragraph: ELSKUS--Ann (nee Crewdson), 82, wife of renowned stained glass artist Albinas Elskus, passed away early Christmas eve at York hospital, Maine, after a brief hospital stay. Born in Lewistown, PA, she grew up in Nitro, WV, eloped with Albinas Elskus in Paris in 1953, and moved to Manhattan in 1954 where they lived for nearly 50 years at Gramercy Arms on 22nd Street. She was a secretary for Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Seitz of Rockefeller University for 20 years. She is survived by their three children, Adria Elskus, Arilda Densch and Albin Elskus, and four grandchildren, Ashley, Brian, Scott and Molly Elskus.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSKUS, ANN (NEE CREWDSON)

snippet: President Obama’s economic advisers should learn from Japan’s lost decade of economic stagnation  half measures don’t work.
lead_paragraph: Thankfully, 2009 ended better than it began. Economists talk about green shoots of recovery taking hold. Consumer confidence has improved. Equity markets have soared. But for all the progress, the American economy remains extremely vulnerable. To understand those economic risks, it is worth considering Japan's experience in the 1990s. A bursting housing bubble there sparked a banking crisis that was followed by a decade of economic stagnation.
abstract: Editorial asserts that while financial indicators show 2009 ended better than it began, American economy remains extremely vulnerable; holds lost decade in Japan marked by decade of economic stagnation was caused by government's failure to intervene, thus making things even worse; fears that US could be on similar path, especially if Congress heeds call to 'cut budget gap' with measures that could halt progress; urges Obama administration to expedite regulatory reform to curb bankers' destructive risk-taking, noting that banks are thinly capitalized and weak and could jeopardize economic well-being
headline: Avoiding a Japanese Decade

snippet: Let it be written that in the first decade of the second millennium a host of gods and goddesses descended on the mortal land of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: O COME, let us adore them. Let it be written that in the first decade of the second millennium a host of gods and goddesses descended on the mortal land of Broadway. Julia, Jude, Hugh, Denzel, Daniel the Elder, Daniel the Younger, Catherine, Katie and he who was called P. Diddy. For these deities, known to all the world from the writ of the tabloids, the people arrived in multitudes, among them heathens who had never set foot in a theater before. And so the Pharisees of Broadway rejoiced, for their coffers were full again and their other expenses were low.

snippet: The San Francisco Symphony’s new Project San Francisco will offer a pair of residency programs with the composer George Benjamin and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between the rock stars of classical music and the orchestras and audiences that interact with them can generally be characterized as a series of memorable one-night stands. When the Lang Langs, Joshua Bells and Renée Flemings of the world arrive in town for an evening or two, tickets fly, and standing ovations shake concert halls. But no sooner has the applause died down than the artists are on a plane to the next city. Lately, however, orchestras across the country have been looking for ways to deepen their relationships with top-tier musicians. Artist residencies, ranging from one week to two years, are now de rigueur. The baritone Thomas Hampson and the composer Magnus Lindberg have lengthy residencies with the New York Philharmonic; the Chicago Symphony recently announced the appointment of the Bay Area composer Mason Bates as a composer in residence; and last year the Los Angeles Philharmonic created the position of creative chair for another Bay Area composer, John Adams.
headline: Asking Stars Not Just to Play, but Also to Stay

snippet: Delicacy International Market has a decidedly Eastern European flavor, with an emphasis on mushrooms, pickled vegetables and cans of fish, and a deli counter.
lead_paragraph: Despite the best intentions, New Year's resolutions seldom last long. Faced with the enticements at Delicacy International Market, resolutions that involve eating less are likely to evaporate. At first glance, this tightly confined store looks like other urban groceries, with a selection of fresh produce -- apples, pears, pomegranates, peppers and whatnot -- by the entrance. But step up to the shelves of canned and jarred goods, and the complexion changes. The display has a decidedly Eastern European flavor, with an emphasis on several mushroom species (including king boletes, $12 for a 24-ounce jar), pickled vegetables and cans of fish (notably mackerel, herring and cod liver, from $2.29 to $4).
headline: A Taste of Eastern Europe

There were no lines at the check-in counters, no lines to clear security and no lineup of idling planes on the runway.

snippet: protohaus Can two lives be crammed into 127 square feet? Ann Holley, 29, a graduate student in sculpture/dimensional studies, and her husband, Darren Macca, 39, an industrial designer, comfortably coexist in their tiny house on Alfred University's...
lead_paragraph: protohaus Can two lives be crammed into 127 square feet? Ann Holley, 29, a graduate student in sculpture/dimensional studies, and her husband, Darren Macca, 39, an industrial designer, comfortably coexist in their tiny house on Alfred University's upstate New York campus. Started as a school project -- a design for simple, efficient living -- ProtoHaus cost $25,000 to build, with reclaimed materials, solar panels, composting toilet, propane refrigerator and wheels. It will travel to wherever Ms. Holley lands a teaching job after graduating this spring. ''We're living smaller -- financially, ecologically, consuming less,'' she says (both get by on five outfits, give or take). ''We're able to spend less time working to support the things in our life and more time just living.'' dome life Jake Weller, a philosophy major at Juniata College in central Pennsylvania, expected the dean of students to laugh when he submitted his proposal to live the year in a geodesic dome on campus. But he not only got permission, he was exempted from student housing fees. Mr. Weller, 19, hopes to lessen his impact with a rain catchment system and composting toilet. His 12 volts of solar energy power a few LED bulbs and his laptop, and he is braving the winter with just a kerosene heater. But he's not totally off the grid: he's still on the college meal plan.
abstract: Profiles of three students who live in unorthodox and homemade, sustainainble housing on campuses; photos (M)
headline: Shelter
