snippet: Ten people were killed as Shabab rebels battled a pro-government group of moderates that had chased them from Dusa Marreb in December 2008.
lead_paragraph: Shabab rebels, who control most of Somalia with allied Islamist groups, on Saturday attacked a town lost to moderate Islamists about a year ago. It appeared late Saturday that the moderate Islamists had kept control of the town, Dusa Marreb, in central Somalia, although the Shabab earlier claimed victory. The battles killed 10 people, witnesses said.
abstract: Moderate Islamist group appears to have kept control of Somali town of Dusa Marreb after attack by Shahab militants; moderate and militant groups have been fighting each other elsewhere in Somalia for months; Western governments hope moderate groups can repel increasingly powerful extremist groups like Shabab (M)
headline: Rival Islamists Fight for Town In Somalia

snippet: This store sells beautiful, functional and affordable Finnish home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: If you had to condense the philosophy behind Finnish home furnishings to one sentence, it might be this: high-quality design should be beautiful, functional and affordable. Still, window-shopping in Helsinki can result in serious sticker shock. On the northern outskirts of town sits a solution: the Iittala outlet store at the Arabia ceramics factory. Built in 1874, the factory, which has spawned over 20 outlet stores around the country, produces tableware for the Arabia and Iittala brands. There, the on-site outlet store Iittala outlet Arabia offers a crash course in 20th- and 21st-century Finnish design -- not to mention discounts of up to 25 percent. Selections range from classic, amoeba-shaped Alvar Aalto vases to contemporary glassware and flatware, along with slightly irregular and special-edition items.
abstract: Sally McGrane Foraging column on shopping for tableware at Iittala outlet store in Helsinki, Finland; photo (M)
headline: Iittala Outlet Arabia: Helsinki, Finland

snippet: Although I am an analytical engineer, the most valuable class I took in 19 years of formal education was marching band. Marching band teaches teamwork, time management, performing under pressure, mistake recovery, mental toughness, dealing with...
lead_paragraph: Although I am an analytical engineer, the most valuable class I took in 19 years of formal education was marching band. Marching band teaches teamwork, time management, performing under pressure, mistake recovery, mental toughness, dealing with difficult people. Professors don't teach those subjects in class, but they are the skills that are most valued in just about every profession. DOUG HALL in response to Gia Kourlas's examination of marching band choreography.
headline: Comment of the Week

snippet: Few in professional sports had a résumé as diverse as Jerry Colangelo's. He was an assistant  with the Chicago Bulls who became the first general manager of the expansion Suns, then came to own the Phoenix franchise, as well as the W.N.B.A.'s...
lead_paragraph: Few in professional sports had a résumé as diverse as Jerry Colangelo's. He was an assistant with the Chicago Bulls who became the first general manager of the expansion Suns, then came to own the Phoenix franchise, as well as the W.N.B.A.'s Mercury and baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks. After the United States men's basketball team's uninspiring performances at the 2002 world championships and the 2004 Olympics in Athens, Colangelo was named the program's managing director and charged with returning it to prominence. The sports columnist Dan Bickley shared the story of the United States' victory at the 2008 Beijing Olympics in a new book, ''Return of the Gold: The Journey of Jerry Colangelo and the Redeem Team.'' Colangelo recently visited the N.B.A. Store in New York to discuss the process. JONATHAN ABRAMS Q. How did you originally become involved with USA Basketball?
abstract: Interview with professional basketball team owner Jerry Colangelo; photo (S)0
headline: A Man Who Knows How to Lead

snippet: <!-- MARY  JOYCE -->JOYCE--Mary Patricia (Pat) Hamill, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, formerly of Morris Plains, New Jersey, died peacefully at home on December 30, 2009 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Frank Joyce, devoted mother of Tara Joyce of Oak...
lead_paragraph: JOYCE--Mary Patricia (Pat) Hamill, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, formerly of Morris Plains, New Jersey, died peacefully at home on December 30, 2009 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Frank Joyce, devoted mother of Tara Joyce of Oak Park, Illinois; Frank Joyce, Jr. (Katy Van Dusen) of Monteverde, Costa Rica; Patricia Joyce (Steven J. Slack) of Ann Arbor, Michigan; and grandchildren Helen, Francis, Richard, Connor, and Devin. Pat will be greatly missed by family and friends. Born in New York in 1931, Pat was a graduate of Mt. St. Ursula Academy and graduated at age 19 from the College of New Rochelle. A memorial Mass will be held at Saint Mary's Abbey in Morristown, New Jersey at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Saint Joseph Mercy Hospice in Ann Arbor, or The Seeing Eye in Morristown, New Jersey.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, MARY

snippet: OWEN--Melvin M.,D.D.S., dentist, inventor, writer, artist passed away quietly on Wednesday, December 23, 2009, in Georgetown, Texas. He was an outstanding dental practitioner in New York City and Ft. Myers, Florida. Mel learned the importance of...
lead_paragraph: OWEN--Melvin M.,D.D.S., dentist, inventor, writer, artist passed away quietly on Wednesday, December 23, 2009, in Georgetown, Texas. He was an outstanding dental practitioner in New York City and Ft. Myers, Florida. Mel learned the importance of painless dentistry from his father and excelled at treating complex and difficult cases. In his efforts to always explore new techniques, he invented a diamond tool that substantially lessened the time preparing teeth for crowns and bridges. Mel's creative genius played out in many other avenues. He wrote stage scripts for numerous musical shows, designed furniture and fixtures, created amazing mobiles, sculptures and metal works, and crafted pottery, where he developed unique glazing techniques. He was among the first to help the blind study textbooks through audio tapes by establishing groups of volunteers to record them. Mel designed "flip books" to help teach activities such as a golf swing and developed a forerunner of today's more advanced golf simulators. Mel was dedicated to the spirit and mission of Rotary International, having been a member at clubs in Ft. Myers and Sun City for many years. He was active in a variety of groups at Sun City Georgetown, including the Sun City Theater Group, the Computer Club, the Solos Club, and the Creative Crafts and Clay Club. Over his lifetime, Mel was active as a tennis player, golfer, snow skier, sailor, boatman, windsurfer, bocce player, and bridge player. He loved to dance with his beautiful wife, Moana Holt Owen. Mel's zest for life encompassed many disciplines. His elegance and refinement lent an air of grace to every event. He could regale partygoers with tales of worldwide travels while charming his partners on the dance floor. Mel was always a gentleman without ceasing to be a gentle man, one whose kindness will be fondly remembered. The true testament to Mel is the warmth and love which he inspired in the hearts of the many fortunate enough to have known him throughout his rich and rewarding life. Mel was born in Brooklyn, NY, on August 13, 1923. After graduating from Erasmus Hall High School, Long Island University, and NYU Dental School, Mel served as an Army dentist in Alaska from 1946-47. He moved with Moana to Cape Coral, Florida, in 1975. After she passed on, he relocated to Sun City Georgetown in 1996. He leaves behind a lifetime treasure of loving memories for his son Mallard Owen and wife Judith Smith of Ashburn, Virginia; his daughter Meredith Owen of Round Rock, Texas; his sister, Alese Owen Pechter; his brother and sister-in-law, Edwin and Nancy Owen; and his nephews, John and Andrew Owen; and Stuart, Richard, Jay and Todd Pechter.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, MELVIN M.

snippet: An article last Sunday about the reaction of states to the costs of expanding Medicaid coverage in the Senate health care bill misstated the length of time the federal government would pay the entire cost of the expansion to people who are not...
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the reaction of states to the costs of expanding Medicaid coverage in the Senate health care bill misstated the length of time the federal government would pay the entire cost of the expansion to people who are not already eligible under state coverage. It is three years (2014 through 2016) -- not two.
abstract: Correction of Dec 27, 2009 article about reaction of states to costs of expanding Medicaid coverage in Senate health care bill
headline: Corrections

snippet: DUNAIF--James G.,died suddenly on December 25, 2009. Born November 10, 1926 in New York City. At the age of 17 he enlisted in the US Merchant Marines and served through the duration of WWII in the North Atlantic. Following his discharge, he worked as...
lead_paragraph: DUNAIF--James G.,died suddenly on December 25, 2009. Born November 10, 1926 in New York City. At the age of 17 he enlisted in the US Merchant Marines and served through the duration of WWII in the North Atlantic. Following his discharge, he worked as a ship sales broker and went on to form his own firm, Cargo Ships and Tankers, Inc., where he owned and operated a fleet of Liberty and Victory ships. Predeceased by parents Charles and Edith, and daughter Audrey. Survived by children Steven (Shari) and Geraldine (Scott) Bethune, grandchildren Jon (Christyn) Bethune, Amy Bethune and Charles C. Dunaif, great-grandson Jackson Bethune. He was loved and will be missed.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAIF, JAMES G.

snippet: BURNS--Mrs. Thomas Robert, Ingrid Lilly, died on December 23, 2009 at home in Palm Beach, FL at the age of 95. She is survived by her loving and beloved daughters, Kathleen Ingrid and Madeleine Deidre Burns; grandchildren Kirsten Camp, Thomas Bartle,...
lead_paragraph: BURNS--Mrs. Thomas Robert, Ingrid Lilly, died on December 23, 2009 at home in Palm Beach, FL at the age of 95. She is survived by her loving and beloved daughters, Kathleen Ingrid and Madeleine Deidre Burns; grandchildren Kirsten Camp, Thomas Bartle, III and Robert Miller. As well as great-granddaughters, Tamarin Camp and Lily Camp. Mrs. Burns was predeceased by the great love of her life, her husband of 56 years, Thomas Robert Burns and her brother, Bill Frohlich. She was a member of the Bath and Tennis Club, the Everglades Club and the Beach Club in Palm Beach, FL; the Colony Club in NYC and the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, NY. Mrs. Burns was the favorite couture model of the Duchess of Windsor and Gypsy Rose Lee. Mrs. Burns was an honorary member of the Royal Society of Medicine in London and the presiding trustee of a family foundation supportive of many New York and Palm Beach charities. The family wishes to express deep gratitude to Dr. Earl Campazzi, Jr, Carmen Garcia and Maria Randtke for their long devotion and care of Mrs. Burns. In lieu of flowers, donations to International House, 500 Riverside Drive, NYC, NY 10027 or Northcentral Maltese Rescue of Florida, 3601 Wright Ave, Racine, WI 53405 would be appreciated. Memorial services will be announced at a later date.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, MRS

snippet: A brief history of the swim test  some colleges still require students to pass one.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, after the media homed in on Lincoln University in Pennsylvania for its requirement that students be tested for body mass index -- and those at obese level be required to take a fitness course to graduate -- the college rescinded the rule. This got us thinking about other fitness tests required for graduation, specifically the dwindling swim test.
abstract: Cornell is one of first universities to reimpose passage of swimming test as requirement to graduate; by 1995, only 5 percent of colleges and universities required tests, citing lack of any physical education requirement as reason; photo; chart (M)

snippet: Iran’s foreign minister said the country could begin further enriching its nuclear stockpile on its own.
lead_paragraph: Iran's foreign minister warned the West on Saturday that it had one month to accept Iran's counterproposal to a deal brokered by the United Nations aimed at slowing the Iranian nuclear program, or else Iran would begin further enriching its nuclear fuel stockpile on its own. The comments by the foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, were broadcast on state television and presented as an ''ultimatum'' to the West just two days after Iran missed a deadline set by the United States and its allies to accept a deal that was brokered in October in Geneva.
abstract: Iranian Foreign Min Manouchehr Mottaki gives West one month to accept unspecified counterproposal to United Nations-brokered plan aimed at slowing its nuclear program; says country will continue enriching uranium on its own in absence of agreement; ultimatum comes two days after Iran missed deadline set by United States and its allies to accept their proposal; photo (M)
headline: Iran Gives West One-Month 'Ultimatum' to Accept Nuclear Counterproposal

Judge Denny Chin of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, for whom the bride was a law clerk, officiated. The bride, 31, is an associate at the New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. She graduated from Dartmouth and received a law degree from Fordham.

snippet: Smoking as social networking.
lead_paragraph: ''Being a smoker is like being part of a social networking system. A cigarette lasts 5 or 10 minutes. In that time you get to know where someone is from, what classes they are taking, what professors are good, who gives too much work. Outside the library, at 3 in the morning, there are 50 kids* taking a smoking break. If you're not a smoker, you're not in it. It's a form of Facebook, really. . . . We all know it's horrible ** for us.'' GENEVIEVE HOLMES,sophomore, American University
abstract: College student and smoker Genevieve Holmes describes social connections forged with other students who smoke (S)
headline: Student Cigarette Break

snippet: EDINBURGH has been on a quest to update its image from a staid academic town to a cultural hot spot with lively festivals, a robust night life and, yes, even fashion. The city's biggest attention-grabber is probably Hotel Missoni, smack in the center...
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH has been on a quest to update its image from a staid academic town to a cultural hot spot with lively festivals, a robust night life and, yes, even fashion. The city's biggest attention-grabber is probably Hotel Missoni, smack in the center of town, which was opened this year by the Italian fashion house in partnership with the Rezidor Hotel Group. Rosita Missoni, the designer known for her vibrant knits, decorated the property, mixing bursts of color, like purple glass walls and blood-orange hallways, into a stark black-and-white palette. Even the doormen's zigzag chevron kilts play well in a city of somber gray stone and medieval spires. Rooms from about $417. 011-44-31-220- 6666. ROCKY CASALE

snippet: The faltering economy provided the United States with at least one silver lining: a narrowing of the trade gap. In 2006, that gap had grown so large that Warren Buffett warned it was a bigger threat to the domestic economy than either the federal...
lead_paragraph: The faltering economy provided the United States with at least one silver lining: a narrowing of the trade gap. In 2006, that gap had grown so large that Warren Buffett warned it was a bigger threat to the domestic economy than either the federal budget deficit or consumer debt. The bursting of the housing bubble and the ensuing credit crisis caused consumer spending to drop abruptly, and imports plunged as a result. Exports fell as well, but not as sharply, so the trade gap shrank from $65 billion in May 2006 to $26 billion in May 2009. But as economists have noted, when the economy began to recover last fall, the trade deficit began to rise again as consumers felt freer to spend money on flat-screen TV's and other luxury items, many of which come from China. Last month, President Obama cautioned that the lopsided trade relationship with China could put enormous economic and political strain on the two countries.

headline: The Trade Seesaw

snippet: After the Dodgers left town in 1957, Alan Titan of Brooklyn was a fan without a team. That changed when he and some City College classmates took the subway one Sunday afternoon to see the debut of a new professional football franchise.     Despite...
lead_paragraph: After the Dodgers left town in 1957, Alan Titan of Brooklyn was a fan without a team. That changed when he and some City College classmates took the subway one Sunday afternoon to see the debut of a new professional football franchise. Despite wet and windy weather and few fans in the decaying Polo Grounds in Upper Manhattan, it was love at first sight for Titan as the New York Titans of the fledgling American Football League defeated the Buffalo Bills, 27-3, on Sept. 11, 1960.

snippet: Osvaldo Hernandez, an Army specialist, said a youthful error had barred him from joining the Police Department. But he planned to reapply on his return from Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: On the day he was to be deployed for another tour in Afghanistan, a young soldier who was pardoned by Gov. David A. Paterson last week for a gun possession conviction said that Army life remained his priority. But his dream of joining the New York Police Department was never far behind. ''I just want to take my experience in the military and put it forth in New York City,'' the soldier, Specialist Osvaldo Hernandez, said on Saturday. ''I want to continue to do public service. I grew up in New York City, so that's just where I want to give back.''
headline: Soldier Says Pardon Buoys His Hopes for Police Career

snippet: The existential crisis of magazines online.
lead_paragraph: But what is a magazine? If you're holding one, you can turn the page. But it's very possible that you're nowhere near a turnable page now. You're reading on a computer or a hand-held device, even though this column was intended for a magazine -- a Sunday newspaper supplement that started in 1896. Like hardcover books in Kindle editions and ''Daily Show'' clips on the Web, this column is produced in large part for a medium other than the one in which it is consumed.
abstract: Virginia Heffernan The Medium column compares online and print magazines; holds that in print versions, traditional elemental order and design are important, but that online readers crave novelty, links and multimedia; suggests magazines may never completely make online transition because adherents seek type of experience that is better offered in print; photo (M)
headline: Articles of Faith

snippet: Janet Napolitano, the homeland security chief, answers questions about the Christmas terrorist plot and how to keep the nation safe.
lead_paragraph: Janet Napolitano and I hadn't planned to spend New Year's Eve together.

snippet: Andre Dixon rushed for 126 yards and a touchdown to help Connecticut defeat South Carolina in the Papajohns.com Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Randy Edsall, the Connecticut football coach, seemed unsettled this week as he watched his team practice for the PapaJohns.com Bowl. The Huskies had been through a trying season, with five defeats by a total of 15 points and a win over Notre Dame in two overtimes. But that was nothing compared to the stabbing death of defensive back Jasper Howard. Edsall wondered if his team had any emotion left. ''I was just worried that the season has been so long and so tough on them, that I didn't see a whole lot of emotion from them,'' Edsall said. ''I guess they were just saving it up for today.''
headline: An Emotional Season for Connecticut Ends in a Victory

snippet: <!-- ANN  ELSKUS -->ELSKUS--Ann (nee Crewdson), 82, wife of renowned stained glass artist Albinas Elskus, passed away early Christmas eve at York hospital, Maine, after a brief hospital stay. Born in Lewistown, PA, she grew up in Nitro, WV, eloped...
lead_paragraph: ELSKUS--Ann (nee Crewdson), 82, wife of renowned stained glass artist Albinas Elskus, passed away early Christmas eve at York hospital, Maine, after a brief hospital stay. Born in Lewistown, PA, she grew up in Nitro, WV, eloped with Albinas Elskus in Paris in 1953, and moved to Manhattan in 1954 where they lived for nearly 50 years at Gramercy Arms on 22nd Street. She was a secretary for Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Seitz of Rockefeller University for 20 years. She is survived by their three children, Adria Elskus, Arilda Densch and Albin Elskus, and four grandchildren, Ashley, Brian, Scott and Molly Elskus.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSKUS, ANN

snippet: Seeking common ground between what a community needs and what a student wants to experience.
lead_paragraph: BETTY MEDINA LICHTENSTEIN used to dread the beginning of the school year, when students from colleges and universities around Holyoke, Mass., would descend on her tiny community organization, Enlace de Familias. ''Suddenly, droves of students were walking through my door, interrupting my day and asking, 'What can I do here?' '' she says. ''A whole other crowd would send résumé after résumé after résumé expecting me to call them back. Still other ones would come in and say, 'How about some research on X?' in August and then show up in late October saying their thesis really needed to be about Y.
headline: Does Service Learning Really Help?

snippet: To the Editor:     In her fine review of Joan Schenkar's ''Talented Miss Highsmith'' (Dec. 20), Jeanette Winterson wrote that Highsmith's antihero Tom Ripley was ''a new kind of criminal, not seen before in crime/murder/detective fiction.'' But at...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In her fine review of Joan Schenkar's ''Talented Miss Highsmith'' (Dec. 20), Jeanette Winterson wrote that Highsmith's antihero Tom Ripley was ''a new kind of criminal, not seen before in crime/murder/detective fiction.'' But at least one such character predates Ripley: Ernest Ralph Gorse, the central figure in three novels by Patrick Hamilton, the British writer perhaps better known for his plays ''Angel Street'' (which was filmed as ''Gaslight'') and ''Rope'' (which became a Hitchcock movie). I don't know if Highsmith ever read the Gorse novels, all of which appeared in the early '50s, but Ripley does share Gorse's amorality, psychopathology and cruel, chameleon-like nature.''
abstract: Ronald De Feo letter comments on Jeanette Winterson Dec 20 review of Joan Schenkar book The Talented Miss Highsmith: The Secret Life and Serious Art of Patricia Highsmith
headline: A Dastardly Duo

snippet: The top pick in the 2009 N.B.A. draft has not played in the regular season after sustaining a stress fracture in his left kneecap in the team’s final preseason game.
lead_paragraph: The shot by Baron Davis didn't even nick the rim, lest it take a typical Clippers bounce and kick out. Instead, it swished right through, a buzzer-beater that upended the Boston Celtics last week and momentarily allowed the Clippers to feel better about a season that will probably end where it often does -- at the door to the N.B.A.'s draft lottery. Still, even this moment, the highlight of the Clippers' season, was tinged with the bittersweet. For amid the mini-mob scene, as Davis was engulfed by his happy teammates, it was easy to spot Blake Griffin, wearing a pinstriped suit instead of a Clippers jersey and still waiting to play his first minutes in the N.B.A.
abstract: Los Angeles Clippers are 14-18, and hoping top overall draft pick Blake Griffin will return soon from fractured kneecap; photo (M)1
headline: Wishing Upon a Star's Return

snippet: LaVALLEE--Elizabeth DeWahl. Known as Beth, died on December 9, 2009 in Belleville, NJ. In a few days she would have been 53. She was known for her sense of humor and quick wit. A graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University, she taught elementary...
lead_paragraph: LaVALLEE--Elizabeth DeWahl. Known as Beth, died on December 9, 2009 in Belleville, NJ. In a few days she would have been 53. She was known for her sense of humor and quick wit. A graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University, she taught elementary school for twenty years in Paterson, NJ, where she was a special education teacher and enjoyed working with children with disabilities. During that time she resided in Ho-Ho-Kus, Parsippany and Hawthorne, NJ. She retired in 2002 because of disabling injuries she suffered in an automobile accident. She has lived in South Orange, NJ for the last six years. Born in New York City, she grew up in Briarcliff Manor, NY and Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. After Beth's automobile accident she was fortunate to discover JESPY, an organization based in South Orange that specializes in providing a community of care and friendship for adults with disabilities. The staff and clients of JESPY, as well as the residents of South Orange, provided a welcoming environment that sustained and enriched her life. She is survived by her father, David A. DeWahl of Vero Beach, FL, an older brother David, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, a younger brother Duncan C. of Maitland, FL, three nephews and two nieces. Her marriage in 1984 ended in divorce. In the last few years she has been cared for by Shan Atkinson. Her death, attributed to sepsis, occurred after a series of operations for a chronic foot ailment. A memorial service, followed by a reception, will be held at 11am on January 9, 2010 at House of Prayer Episcopal Church, 407 Broad Street, Newark, NJ. The family requests that no flowers be sent.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVALLEE, ELIZABETH DEWAHL

snippet: If you're a lawyer presenting an oral argument before Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, never, ever use the word choate. No, not the name Choate (rhymes with ''boat''), which graces a Connecticut prep school and the great 19th-century...
lead_paragraph: If you're a lawyer presenting an oral argument before Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, never, ever use the word choate. No, not the name Choate (rhymes with ''boat''), which graces a Connecticut prep school and the great 19th-century jurist Rufus Choate. The taboo term is choate (pronounced KOH-it or KOH-ate), an adjective defined by Webster's New World Law Dictionary as ''completed or perfected in and of itself'' and formed as the opposite of inchoate (''commenced but not completed, partially done''). A lawyer named Randolph Barnhouse learned this lesson the hard way in November when he appeared before the Supreme Court as counsel to a company selling tax-free cigarettes over the Internet. Barnhouse said the opportunity to recover taxes on the cigarettes was an ''inchoate'' interest, not yet fully formed. ''Any recovery would not be property until it became choate, until there was an amount of money assigned to it,'' he explained.
abstract: Ben Zimmer On Language column on Justice Antonin Scalia's upbraiding of lawyer for using 'choate' as opposite of 'inchoate' during oral argument; Scalia claims it is not proper word; drawing (M)
headline: Choate

snippet: Despite hopes for a continued surge in 2010, data shows that market gains in one year reveal little about the next.
lead_paragraph: A STOCK that builds momentum in one year often carries it over into the next. Might that momentum effect work for the overall stock market? It's an especially tantalizing prospect right now, after the market's surge over the last nine months of 2009. Investors would love to see that trend continue into this year.
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column notes stocks surged in last nine months of 2009, holds that market's performance in one year cannot predict next year; photo (M)
headline: What The Past Can't Tell Investors

snippet: If you've attended a pro football game at Giants Stadium, you've probably noticed the sea gulls riding the wind high above the upper deck, sailing and swooping before diving toward the parking lots for the tailgate leftovers. And with the stadium...
lead_paragraph: If you've attended a pro football game at Giants Stadium, you've probably noticed the sea gulls riding the wind high above the upper deck, sailing and swooping before diving toward the parking lots for the tailgate leftovers. And with the stadium about to close, whenever I've looked up to see those sea gulls while covering Giants and Jets games, I remember the afternoon a small plane suddenly appeared. Three weeks after Joe Pisarcik's famous fumble in 1978 assured the Giants' 15th straight season of not qualifying for the playoffs, that small plane towed a banner: ''15 Years of Lousy Football. We've Had Enough.'' Having been alerted by fliers passed out by members of a ''Giants Fan Committee,'' the 52,226 parishioners in attendance (there were 24,374 no-shows) began to chant: ''We've had enough! We've had enough!''
abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses memorable moments at Giants Stadium; photo (M)
headline: Before Giants Stadium Closes, Making One Last Fly-By

snippet: We denounce the Great Male Novelists of the last century for their sexism. But something has been lost now that innocence is more fashionable than virility, the cuddle preferable to sex.
lead_paragraph: For a literary culture that fears it is on the brink of total annihilation, we are awfully cavalier about the Great Male Novelists of the last century. It has become popular to denounce those authors, and more particularly to deride the sex scenes in their novels. Even the young male writers who, in the scope of their ambition, would appear to be the heirs apparent have repudiated the aggressive virility of their predecessors. After reading a sex scene in Philip Roth's latest novel, ''The Humbling,'' someone I know threw the book into the trash on a subway platform. It was not exactly feminist rage that motivated her. We have internalized the feminist critique pioneered by Kate Millett in ''Sexual Politics'' so completely that, as one of my students put it, ''we can do the math ourselves.'' Instead my acquaintance threw the book away on the grounds that the scene was disgusting, dated, redundant. But why, I kept wondering, did she have to throw it out? Did it perhaps retain a little of the provocative fire its author might have hoped for? Dovetailing with this private and admittedly limited anecdote, there is a punitive, vituperative quality in the published reviews that is always revealing of something larger in the culture, something beyond one aging writer's failure to produce fine enough sentences. All of which is to say: How is it possible that Philip Roth's sex scenes are still enraging us?
abstract: Katie Roiphe article compares generational attitudes in sex scenes written by male novelists of last century; drawings (M)
headline: The Naked And the Conflicted

snippet: To keep a middle-aged mind sharp, shake up what you already know.
lead_paragraph: I LOVE reading history, and the shelves in my living room are lined with fat, fact-filled books. There's ''The Hemingses of Monticello,'' about the family of Thomas Jefferson's slave mistress; there's ''House of Cards,'' about the fall of Bear Stearns; there's ''Titan,'' about John D. Rockefeller Sr. The problem is, as much as I've enjoyed these books, I don't really remember reading any of them. Certainly I know the main points. But didn't I, after underlining all those interesting parts, retain anything else? It's maddening and, sorry to say, not all that unusual for a brain at middle age: I don't just forget whole books, but movies I just saw, breakfasts I just ate, and the names, oh, the names are awful. Who are you?
abstract: Adult learners concerned about aptitude of middle age brains are heartened by research; scientists who study how brains age confirm that they continue to develop through and beyond middle age; find healthy brain will keep on building pathways that help its owner recognize patterns and see solutions faster than young person can; experts say confronting thoughts that are contrary to one's own is good way to keep brain connections good; photos (M)
headline: How to Train the Aging Brain

snippet: THE REALITY     If you've written a few five-figure tuition checks or taken on 10 years' of debt, you probably think you're paying to be taught by full-time professors. But it's entirely possible that most of your teachers are freelancers.
lead_paragraph: THE REALITY If you've written a few five-figure tuition checks or taken on 10 years' of debt, you probably think you're paying to be taught by full-time professors. But it's entirely possible that most of your teachers are freelancers.

snippet: David Levine’s line came from caricaturists of the past, but he used it to untangle the politics of his day.
lead_paragraph: Caricature works wonders at skewering puffed-up demigods, moguls and celebrities by ripping off their false facades. For artists it is both a vent for frustration and a tool of dissent, but being good at it is never easy. Just getting a good likeness is hard enough; making it into a truly smart distortion takes a master manipulator. From the mid-'60s through the early 2000s, American caricature was most ingeniously and influentially practiced by the Brooklyn-born caricaturist and painter David Levine, who died at 83 on Dec. 29 of prostate cancer and other illnesses. Given the thousands of drawings he produced during his lengthy career, primarily for The New York Review of Books, but also for other periodicals, including Esquire, The New Yorker, Time and The New York Times, he laid claim to a distinctive linear style that was mimicked for decades by scores of less gifted cartoonists. The Levine line was as emblematic of his era -- from the Vietnam War through the Iraq War, covering presidents from Kennedy to Obama -- as were the graphic styles of the 19th- and early-20th-century cartoon luminaries Honoré Daumier, Thomas Nast and George Grosz.
abstract: David Levine, who died in Dec 2009, was master at using caricature in his political cartoons to add insightfully comic graphic commentary; his style was throwback to French caricaturist Andre Gill and British cartoonist John Tenniel; he was leader in portraying social and political tumult from mid-1960s through early 2000s and had great influence on younger practitioners of art; drawings (M)
headline: Insight by a Thousand Strokes

snippet: Andheri has reinvented itself into a destination neighborhood full of elegant flats, trendy restaurants and homegrown boutiques.
lead_paragraph: UNTIL the last few years, Andheri in North Mumbai was best known for being the largest suburb in India's largest city. Industrial offices and dirt-caked apartment buildings framed streets so densely packed with cars and scooters that traveling a mile could easily take a half-hour. Today, the traffic is thicker than ever, but this once-bland area has reinvented itself into a destination neighborhood full of elegant flats, trendy restaurants and bars, top-quality spas and a mix of big name-brand stores and homegrown boutiques.
abstract: Shivani Vora travel article on transformation of Mumbai suburb of Andheri into destination neighborhood full of elegant apartments, trendy restaurants and bars and top-quality spas and boutiques; photo; map (M)

snippet: Palita Gbalajobi wants to work, and she will push her body to the brink to do it.
lead_paragraph: Palita Gbalajobi wants to work, and she will push her body to the brink to do it. ''I can't see nothing at all, just down,'' she said one afternoon in her living room in Canarsie, Brooklyn, covering her good eye. Ms. Gbalajobi, (pronounced Jeh-ba-la-jo-bi) 70, does not let partial blindness stop her from seeking work.
abstract: Unemployed home health attendant Palita Gbalajobi received help to pay her rent from Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven beneficiary agencies of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)
headline: A Woman's Desire to Work Is Thwarted by a Body That Strains to Keep Up

snippet: Keeping birds away from airports  and thus, out of airplane engines  is no easy job, particularly at Kennedy, which was built in wetlands.
lead_paragraph: SHE was driving on the grounds of Kennedy International Airport and talking about the importance of keeping the grass 6 to 10 inches long when she spotted something out of the corner of her eye: a sea gull, standing on the tip of a runway. She hit the gas and cranked the steering wheel and charged straight for it. The bird flew away. The driver, Laura C. Francoeur, paused in a ''now where was I?'' way, then resumed her tutorial on how to keep birds away from airplanes.
headline: Working to Separate Big and Small Fliers

snippet: When a TV show comes calling, the disrepair can no longer be ignored.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny afternoon last spring, a young man rang our doorbell, clipboard in hand, looking like every earnest canvasser who ever came to call. But he wasn't there for my signature. He was there to inform me that the spectacularly unkempt appearance of our house had made us likely candidates for a free facade makeover on a new TV show titled: ''Your Neighbors Must Really Hate You.'' (Not actually, but that was the none-too-subtle subtext.) Though my visitor waxed rhapsodic about our busted shutters and two-story-high hedge, I felt more as if I were receiving a diagnosis than a prize. I'd spent years convincing myself that the house wasn't really that bad, and now here was this oddly enthusiastic stranger dismantling my delusion. At one point, as he took pictures, I muttered, ''Lord,'' and he muttered, ''I really do hate this part of my job.'' But very soon, with only negligible resistance on my part, we slipped from the norms of decent society into another set: the norms of reality TV.
abstract: Robin Black Lives column describes what it was like being told that unkempt appearance of her house made her possible contestant on reality television makeover program Your Neighbors Must Reallly Hate You; drawing (M)
headline: Reality Knocks

snippet: The why-can’t-we-all-get-along issues have haunted American intelligence for six decades.
lead_paragraph: This time, at least, disaster was averted. But the parallels between Christmas Day and Sept. 11, 2001, were inescapable: a radical Islamist, an airplane, explosives that came close to destroying innocent lives. And -- perhaps most alarming -- the apparent failure of American intelligence to uncover an imminent terrorist attack despite what seemed ample clues.
abstract: Theorists and practitioners of intelligence-gathering seek smoothly functioning system but are more often faced with poor communications among agencies that often work at cross purposes; this was highlighted in Christmas Day bombing attempt; problem is compounded by nature of adversary: loose global network of jihadists; Sherman Kent, who authored classic book Strategic Intelligence for American World Policy, prized art of data accumulation and nonideological analysis; opposite view was taken by onetime CIA advisor Willmore Kendall, who criticized Kent as being preoccupied with prediction; photo (M)
headline: The DNA Problem in American Spying

snippet: LaVALLEE--Elizabeth DeWahl. Known as Beth, died on December 9, 2009...
lead_paragraph: LaVALLEE--Elizabeth DeWahl. Known as Beth, died on December 9, 2009 in Belleville, NJ. In a few days she would have been 53. She was known for her sense of humor and quick wit. A graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University, she taught elementary school for twenty years in Paterson, NJ, where she was a special education teacher and enjoyed working with children with disabilities. During that time she resided in Ho-Ho-Kus, Parsippany and Hawthorne, NJ. She retired in 2002 because of disabling injuries she suffered in an automobile accident. She has lived in South Orange, NJ for the last six years. Born in New York City, she grew up in Briarcliff Manor, NY and Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. After Beth's automobile accident she was fortunate to discover JESPY, an organization based in South Orange that specializes in providing a community of care and friendship for adults with disabilities. The staff and clients of JESPY, as well as the residents of South Orange, provided a welcoming environment that sustained and enriched her life. She is survived by her father, David A. DeWahl of Vero Beach, FL, an older brother David, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, a younger brother Duncan C. of Maitland, FL, three nephews and two nieces. Her marriage in 1984 ended in divorce. In the last few years she has been cared for by Shan Atkinson. Her death, attributed to sepsis, occurred after a series of operations for a chronic foot ailment. A memorial service, followed by a reception, will be held at 11am on January 9, 2010 at House of Prayer Episcopal Church, 407 Broad Street, Newark, NJ. The family requests that no flowers be sent.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVALLEE, ELIZABETH

snippet: <!-- WILLIAM D MCGUINNESS -->McGUINNESS--William D., of Norwalk, CT, age 87, died surrounded by his family on December 15, 2009. Bill was the husband of Catherine (Murphy) McGuinness, who predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Kenneth D....
lead_paragraph: McGUINNESS--William D., of Norwalk, CT, age 87, died surrounded by his family on December 15, 2009. Bill was the husband of Catherine (Murphy) McGuinness, who predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Kenneth D. McGuinness, and his wife, Jeanne Anne Norton of Albany and New York, NY; Monica M. McNally, and her husband, Francis of Lee, NH; Sheila M. Wall, and her husband, Richard of Norwalk, CT and Wm. Danner McGuinness, Jr. and his wife Lorena of Albany, NY, and 11 grandchildren. Mr. McGuinness was born in New York, NY. He graduated from Brooklyn College, NYU and the Harvard AMP Program. He was a WWII veteran, serving in the Battle of the Bulge. He served in various insurance/finance capacities for the following companies: Flintkote, the Port Authority of NYNJ, Exxon and subsidiaries, ultimately retiring in 1985 as Treasurer of Gulf Oil Corporation. He will be remembered for his determination, resiliency, educational patronage and passion. A mass will be held at 11:30am on January 9, 2010 at St. Jerome RC Church, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Running Strong for American Indian Youth at P.O. Box 670, Raton, NM 87740, the Second Genesis Foundation at 8611 Second Ave, Suite 300, Silver Springs, MD 20910, or Connecticut Hospice, 1 Park St., Norwalk, CT 06851. For more information, please visit: www.collinsfh.com.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, WILLIAM D.

snippet: Tuition vouchers, for sale on Craigs­list. A deal?
lead_paragraph: HERE'S what you could buy on a recent Craigslist: a Maytag stackable for $350, a vintage Schwinn for $120 and a voucher for a 1.5-credit-hour course at St. John's University for $1,000. This tuition deal -- as much as $800 off the sticker price, depending on the program -- was being offered recently by a second-grade teacher on Long Island, who had received the voucher from St. John's.
abstract: Colleges give away tuition vouchers ranging from several hundred upward to few thousand dollars to lure students, as refunds or most often, to thank veteran teachers for welcoming their student teachers into their classrooms; vibrant market has taken root on Craigslist, particularly in New York, with vouchers for sale at steep discounts, even though intention is that they not be sold; photos (M)
headline: Scalping Courses

snippet: Unpredictability is the human quality that makes for compelling sports theater, but a decade from now, a critical story line will be how we watch and how much.
lead_paragraph: In 10 eventful years, LeBron James will be the celebrated elder statesman of the N.B.A., Alex Rodriguez will be baseball's home run champ and Tiger Woods will be a corporate powerhouse again as the record-holder for golf majors. Or James will wind up as ringless as Patrick Ewing, Rodriguez's body will betray him before he catches Barry Bonds, and Woods will be an embittered 44-year-old recluse.

snippet: PENDLETON--Miles S.,Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel Aviv, Bujumbura, Brussels,...
lead_paragraph: PENDLETON--Miles S.,Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel Aviv, Bujumbura, Brussels, London, Paris and Washington, DC. In retirement he was active in the Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Research Consortium and The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. Born in Montclair, NJ on March 22, 1939, Kim Pendleton grew up in Andover, MA, graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, and Yale College, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, and received a Masters in Public Administration from Harvard University in 1967 and a diploma from the National War College in 1980. He was the son of Miles S. Pendleton and Lucille Bond Pendleton. He taught in Ghana from 1962 to 1964. He joined the U.S. Foreign Service in 1967 was assigned to Tel Aviv, where he served as a vice consul and staff assistant to the ambassador, Walworth Barbour, followed by a tour in Bujumbura during the ethnic strife between Tutsis and Hutus in 1972. In Washington DC, he served as a staff officer on the Secretariat Staff, going on several of the Kissinger shuttle flights, and then special assistant to Robert S Ingersoll, the Deputy Secretary of State, 1974-1976. From 1979 to 1985 he served as Deputy Director of the Office of Northern European Affairs during the Falkland Islands War in the spring of 1982, Director of the Office of Israel and Arab-Israel Affairs during the Israeli Lebanon incursion later in 1982, and Executive Assistant to Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. He was Minister Counselor for Political Affairs in London from 1985 to 1989 and Paris from 1989 to 1993. Known for his ready smile and white hair, he surrounded himself with friends, loved conversation, and treated anyone he met with consideration and kindness. Courageous and honest in all matters, but particularly in facing cancer, he possessed a keen, independent mind and was passionate for the causes he supported including the schools he loved. He loved to be in Maine, to sail, and to read The New York Times and The Washington Post. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Elisabeth Morgan Pendleton, his son Nathaniel Pendleton of Washington, DC, his daughter Constance Pendleton and son-in-law Jason Gross of Washington DC and a grandson, a brother, Lea Pendleton of Marblehead, MA and a sister Lissa Pendleton of Westford, MA. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 14 at 11am at St Alban's Episcopal Church, 3001 Wisconsin Ave, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Trustees of Phillips Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810-4161 www.andover.edu or the Washington Hospital Center Foundation 110 Irving Street NW, EB 1001, Washington DC 20010-2975 for the benefit of the Washington Cancer Institute, www.whcenter.org/foundation
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDLETON, MILES S.

snippet: Does someone with tenure deserve a better room? If you listen, must you pay your share?
lead_paragraph: I am a faculty member at a university undergoing major campus renovations, including new office spaces. Departments were asked to determine their own ways of assigning rooms, but the task is complicated by factors like seniority and rank -- does someone with tenure deserve a better room? Some faculty members have greater teaching demands and might need larger rooms to meet with students. What is the most ethical way to allocate offices: seniority? Rank? Lottery? JOHN NICHOLS, WILLIAMSBURG, VA. It is admirable that you and your colleagues seek a fair approach. If only it were easy to devise one. A professor I consulted, a longtime friend, sighed, if one can sigh by e-mail: ''I think it'll be a matter of which method is the least unfair rather than the most fair.''
abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist column responds to query about whether tenure should be determining factor in assignment of offices within college departments; also answers question about public radio listeners who decide not to contribute to stations if they do not agree with how money is spent; drawing (M)
headline: Who Gets the Best Offices?

snippet: Minnesota needs a victory in its regular-season finale, and a loss or a tie by Philadelphia, to clinch a first-round bye.
lead_paragraph: At the south end of the Minnesota Vikings' chilly Winter Park field house Thursday, defensive players broke into position groups to start practice. Quickly, assistants offered telling signs of how the suddenly vulnerable Vikings defense might deal with two critical injuries in Sunday's game against the Giants at the Metrodome. The massive run-stopping tackle Pat Williams, his right elbow in a brace, stood to the side while the defensive line coach Karl Dunbar walked his starters through the finer points of the Giants' zone-blocking techniques. And in the middle of the field, the veteran cornerback Antoine Winfield -- playing through a right foot injury -- took an inside position in the Vikings' package of six defensive backs, instead of lining up on an outside receiver as he usually does.
abstract: Minnesota Vikings prepare to face New York Giants (M)0
headline: Giants Have Lots of Time Off Ahead, but the Vikings Are Hoping for a Week

snippet: After an improbable rise from the Bronx projects to a job selling Gulf Coast homes, Isabel Bermudez lost it all to an epic housing bust -- the six-figure income, the house with the pool and the investment property.     Now, as she papers the county...
lead_paragraph: After an improbable rise from the Bronx projects to a job selling Gulf Coast homes, Isabel Bermudez lost it all to an epic housing bust -- the six-figure income, the house with the pool and the investment property. Now, as she papers the county with résumés and girds herself for rejection, she is supporting two daughters on an income that inspires a double take: zero dollars in monthly cash and a few hundred dollars in food stamps.
abstract: Article in series The Safety Net, examining how social safety net is holding up during fiscal crisis, notes that about six million Americans receiving food stamps report they have no other income; number of people with no cash income was rising even before recession as tougher welfare laws made it harder for poor people to get cash aid, but it has soared about 50 percent in past two years; main cash welfare program has scarcely expanded during recession; its rolls are still down about 75 percent from their 1990s peak; food stamps, which are easier to get, have become safety net of last resort; critics say lack of cash support shows safety net is torn; maps; graphs; photos (L)
headline: Living on Nothing but Food Stamps

snippet: A 9-year-old boy was fatally stabbed at a sprawling apartment complex in Upper Manhattan, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested a 25-year-old man and charged him with the murder of a 9-year-old boy who was fatally stabbed early Saturday in Upper Manhattan, the police said. The boy, whom the police identified as Anthony Maldonado of Palisades Park, N.J., had been in Manhattan to spend time with his mother's family during the holidays, the police said. After several hours of questioning at the 26th Precinct station house, the police arrested the man, Alejandro Morales, who had been in the sixth-floor apartment of an aunt and uncle with whom Anthony had been staying.
abstract: Police arrest Alejandro Morales in stabbing death of 9-year-old cousin Anthony Maldonado in Upper Manhattan; Maldonado had come from Palisades Park, NJ, to visit his mother's family; photo (M)
headline: Boy, 9, Fatally Stabbed During Manhattan Visit

snippet: The events of 9/11 gave birth to specialized programs designed to school students in protection against domestic and international terrorism.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE 9/11, the term ''homeland security'' didn't exist. Neither did the academic discipline. The events of that day changed that. Security experts -- like Vincent Henry, a police officer turned Fulbright scholar who heads the Homeland Security Management Institute at Long Island University -- recognized that an entirely new, specialized industry would have to be formed, and that managers and executives would have to be schooled in the ways of domestic and international terrorism to fill a security void. Eight years later, homeland security is still an emergent field, says Jim Ramsay, coordinator of the homeland security program at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Fla. Mr. Ramsay describes homeland security as a ''meta-discipline, much like medicine, within which there are tons of different functions and specialties -- from the guy who wears Kevlar and walks the Mexican border to the cerebral policy analyst'' who sets the national security agenda. Education and training, he says, are essential in building this workforce.
abstract: Eight years after Sept 11, academic field of homeland security is still emerging; security experts describe it as meta-discipline of different functions and specialties, citing education and training as essential; by 2012, nearly one-quarter of all federal jobs will be related to homeland security; to meet demand, universities have created master's degrees in field, including studies in domestic and international terrorism and emergency management; photo (M)
headline: Safety First

snippet: Because songs are small chunks of information that many people want, music was the canary in the digital coal mine.
lead_paragraph: MY 21st century started in 1998, when I got a new toy. It was the Diamond Rio PMP300, a flimsy plastic gadget the size of a cigarette pack. PMP stood for Portable Music Player. It had a headphone jack, and it played a recently invented digital file format: MPEG-1 Audio Layer Three, or MP3. The Rio's 32 megabytes of storage held a dozen songs at passable fidelity. Its sound was clearly inferior to a portable CD player; its capacity was comparable to a cassette or two. But the beauty of it was that it didn't need any CD or cassette inserted, just digital files -- copies of songs -- loaded from a computer, to be changed at whim. They might come from albums people owned or borrowed; they might come, even back then, from strangers online. The Recording Industry Association of America sued to have the PMP300 taken off the market and failed -- the prelude to a decade of lawsuits trying to corral online music.
abstract: Jon Pareles article on how music world has been affected by modern technology from MP3 players through CDs and now the Internet; new music and new means of distribution discussed; photos (L)
headline: A World Of Megabeats And Megabytes

lead_paragraph: In 10 eventful years, LeBron James will be the celebrated elder statesman of the N.B.A., Alex Rodriguez will be baseball's home run champ and Tiger Woods will be a corporate powerhouse again as the record-holder for golf majors. snippet: PENDLETON--Miles S.,Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel Aviv, Bujumbura, Brussels,...
lead_paragraph: PENDLETON--Miles S.,Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel Aviv, Bujumbura, Brussels, London, Paris and Washington, DC. In retirement he was active in the Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Research Consortium and The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. Born in Montclair, NJ on March 22, 1939, Kim Pendleton grew up in Andover, MA, graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, and Yale College, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, and received a Masters in Public Administration from Harvard University in 1967 and a diploma from the National War College in 1980. He was the son of Miles S. Pendleton and Lucille Bond Pendleton. He taught in Ghana from 1962 to 1964. He joined the U.S. Foreign Service in 1967 was assigned to Tel Aviv, where he served as a vice consul and staff assistant to the ambassador, Walworth Barbour, followed by a tour in Bujumbura during the ethnic strife between Tutsis and Hutus in 1972. In Washington DC, he served as a staff officer on the Secretariat Staff, going on several of the Kissinger shuttle flights, and then special assistant to Robert S Ingersoll, the Deputy Secretary of State, 1974-1976. From 1979 to 1985 he served as Deputy Director of the Office of Northern European Affairs during the Falkland Islands War in the spring of 1982, Director of the Office of Israel and Arab-Israel Affairs during the Israeli Lebanon incursion later in 1982, and Executive Assistant to Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. He was Minister Counselor for Political Affairs in London from 1985 to 1989 and Paris from 1989 to 1993. Known for his ready smile and white hair, he surrounded himself with friends, loved conversation, and treated anyone he met with consideration and kindness. Courageous and honest in all matters, but particularly in facing cancer, he possessed a keen, independent mind and was passionate for the causes he supported including the schools he loved. He loved to be in Maine, to sail, and to read The New York Times and The Washington Post. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Elisabeth Morgan Pendleton, his son Nathaniel Pendleton of Washington, DC, his daughter Constance Pendleton and son-in-law Jason Gross of Washington DC and a grandson, a brother, Lea Pendleton of Marblehead, MA and a sister Lissa Pendleton of Westford, MA. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 14 at 11am at St Alban's Episcopal Church, 3001 Wisconsin Ave, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Trustees of Phillips Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810-4161 www.andover.edu or the Washington Hospital Center Foundation 110 Irving Street NW, EB 1001, Washington DC 20010-2975 for the benefit of the Washington Cancer Institute, www.whcenter.org/foundation
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDLETON, MILES S.

snippet: The works in “Life Objects,” a Princeton University exhibition, reflect connections between African art and ritual beliefs.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition ''Life Objects: Rites of Passage in African Art'' at the Princeton University Art Museum presents 23 outstanding works from the museum's own fine collection, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of African Art and a handful of private collections. Each object is among the very best of its kind in this country. The sheer beauty of the works, along with the range of styles and media represented, attest to the strength of artistic traditions in Africa and the creativity of individual artists there. But this is more than just another sampler show from Africa, for the curators, Chika Okeke-Agulu and Holly W. Ross, have an edifying reason for corralling these works in one place.
headline: Strength and Creativity

snippet: Situated just below the city of Hartford, Newington has managed to avoid a real estate downturn.
lead_paragraph: NEWINGTON SITUATED just below the city of Hartford, the midsized community of Newington lacks the pristinely kept historic districts, scenic rivers and executive neighborhoods prized by many of its suburban neighbors. What it has to offer is more practical: easy access to major highways, lots of modest houses on equally modest lots and a competitive property tax rate.
abstract: In hobbled real estate market, Newington, Conn, is only one of 17 area towns that has actually cycled back into seller's market for single-family homes; homes now on market in Newington can be expected to sell within enviably short period of three months; agents agree that driving factor is price--70 or so houses now listed range from $104,000 to $569,000 with median asking price of $249,900; photo (M)
headline: A Town Where Sellers Smile

snippet: 35 billion: The amount in dollars that Chinese officials misused or embezzled in the first 11 months of 2009.
lead_paragraph: 35 billion: The amount in dollars that Chinese officials misused or embezzled in the first 11 months of 2009, according to a national audit released last week. The announcement was the latest indication of how widespread corruption has become among government agencies and how difficult it will be for Beijing to root it out. The audit of nearly 100,000 government departments and state-owned companies found officials engaged in laundering money, issuing fraudulent loans and cheating the government through the sale or purchase of state property. More than 1,000 officials were facing prosecution or disciplinary action as a result of the audits, the government's National Audit Office said.
abstract: National audit in China shows that officials misused or embezzled $35 billion in first 11 months of 2009, indicating how widespread corruption has become among government agencies and how difficult it will be for Beijing to halt it (S)
headline: 35 billion

snippet: <!-- ROBERT H. SMITH -->SMITH--Robert H. On behalf of The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington, we wish to express our deepest sorrow at the untimely passing of Robert H. Smith z"l. Bob's business and philanthropic leadership here in Washington,...
lead_paragraph: SMITH--Robert H. On behalf of The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington, we wish to express our deepest sorrow at the untimely passing of Robert H. Smith z"l. Bob's business and philanthropic leadership here in Washington, in Israel, and throughout the world was legendary. He translated his passions for the arts, for higher education, for Jewish day school education, for strengthening the Jewish community, for preserving some of America's most significant historical sites, and for so many other causes, into innumerable good deeds. His integral role as both a business and a philanthropic partner of the Smith-Kogod family has enriched our community beyond measure. To Clarice, David, Michelle, Stacey, Michael, Alexandra and Max; to Arlene and Bob Kogod; and to the entire Smith-Kogod family, we express our deepest sympathy. May his name and his memory be for a blessing. We are grateful for his legacy and bereft at his loss. Susie Gelman President The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington Misha Galperin Ph.D. Executive Vice President and CEO The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT H.

snippet: The worst may not be over. Dorms are hotbeds of contagion, especially after winter break.
lead_paragraph: THE tiny, rectangular rooms with twin beds separated by only a few feet. The buffet-style dining halls. The communal bathrooms, whose patrons sometimes pad around carelessly in bare feet. There are few living arrangements, doctors say with a shudder, that are more fraught with contamination possibilities than the college dorm. ''I would call them a public health challenge, to say the least,'' says Dr. Margaret Spear, the director of university health services at Penn State, where roughly two-thirds of the students live in dorms. Dorms have been the target of anti-flu efforts since last spring, when worries about swine flu were at a fever pitch. Colleges have papered walls with posters about hand washing and vaccination, installed freestanding Purell dispensers in entryways and set up rooms where sick students can stay in isolation.
abstract: College dorms, long considered public health challenge, have been target of anti-flu efforts since last spring, when worries about swine flu were high; college officials still fear wave of virus in early 2010; another nagging concern is seasonal flu, as well as other student illnesses; doctors say combination of close quarters and unsanitary conditions causes quick spread of illness in dorms; photo (M)
headline: Going Viral

Most colleges don't even check immigration status when students apply for financial aid -- only 31 percent, according to a survey last year by the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers.

snippet: Memoirs by Stephen Elliott and Richard Rushfield; and essay collections from Chuck Klosterman and Daniel Nester.
lead_paragraph: EATING THE DINOSAUR By Chuck Klosterman. Scribner, $25. There is considerable risk in trying to write intelligently about stupid stuff. Maybe a subject will be so superficial -- Abba, advertising, TV coverage of pro sports -- as to resist all inquisitions. Or maybe, as Klosterman believes, that's a stupid, lazy way to think. ''I've spent an inordinate amount of time searching for the underrated value in ostensibly stupid things,'' he writes in ''Eating the Dinosaur.'' In the course of the collection's 13 essays, Klosterman burrows into overexposed but underexplored departments of American pop culture. Declaring himself ''post-taste,'' he evaluates not the merits of certain phenomena but the ways we ''use'' them. He is unfailingly sincere, brimming with empathy, occasionally depressive and often weepy. Writing about the burnout of the basketball star Ralph Sampson in an essay about how we make some celebrities our ''slaves,'' Klosterman says, ''It seems to exemplify the saddest thing about sports and culture, which means it's pretty much the saddest thing about life that doesn't involve death or secrets.'' On canned laughter: ''Build a machine that tells people when to cry. That's what we need. We need more crying.'' Such statements reveal the depth of Klosterman's obsessions, to which he is of course entitled, though he may be slightly exaggerating the importance of sports. But Klosterman doesn't think he is exaggerating; his essays rely on his deeply personal momentum. He agonizes over his material, offering himself as whipping boy, that he might take on our collective cultural sins.
abstract: Gregory Beyer reviews books Eating the Dinosaur by Chuck Klosterman, The Adderall Diaries: A Memoir of Moods, Masochism, and Murder by Stephen Elliott, Don't Follow Me, I'm Lost: A Memoir of Hampshire College in the Twilight of the 80's by Richard Rushfield and How To Be Inappropriate by Daniel Nester; photos from book Burtynsky: Oil by Edward Burtynsky (M)
headline: Nonfiction Chronicle

snippet: Even though home prices have stabilized, fewer people have enough equity in their homes to qualify for a line of credit.
lead_paragraph: HOME equity lines of credit, once a staple of home finance, have been fading from view, and not only because securing credit is generally more difficult. As borrowers also grow more fiscally conservative, industry experts say, many are becoming reluctant to take on these second mortgages. Helocs, as they're known in the industry, are typically open-ended revolving credit products, with interest rates pegged to the prime lending rate, which banks offer their best customers.
headline: A Trickle From the Equity Tap

snippet: A singer, songwriter and fiddle player soon to release an album of cover songs, talks about the struggle to forge her musical identity.
lead_paragraph: THE fiddle-playing singer-songwriter Carrie Rodriguez knows audiences in Connecticut are used to performers belting out the familiar songs of well-loved artists rather than their own original material. So when she plays two dates here this month, she plans a when-in-Rome approach. ''It's not like I'm going to do bar-band stuff like Creedence Clearwater Revival covers,'' Ms. Rodriguez, 31, said recently. ''But I do have a Lucinda Williams cover, a Townes Van Zandt cover, a cover of a song from an old band called Little Village that had John Hiatt and Ry Cooder in it.''
headline: Finding Her Voice, and Her Way in the World

snippet: Highly specialized master’s programs provide a field guide to the zeitgeist. There are degrees to fit every niche and new twist in the culture.
lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time there were largely two kinds of master's degrees: one was a way station to a doctorate and the other overqualified you to be underpaid as a social worker or helped you get a salary bump as a public school teacher. And then came the quiet revolution. Spawned by a realization in university circles that master's programs could be wildly profitable -- especially within low-cost departments of continuing education -- and a growing sense that in a shifting employment market the best jobs would require specialized training, such degrees have exploded. Nearly twice as many master's degrees were awarded in 2008 than in 1980.
abstract: Twice as many master's degrees were awarded in 2008 than in 1980; universities, strapped for cash, see profitablility in master's programs; students, both recent college graduates and career changers, realize that, in shifting employment market, best jobs require specialized training (S)
headline: 10 Master's Of The New Universe

snippet: In Yemen, the United States must make sure officials permanently lock up terrorists and do not allow them to escape or receive pardons.
lead_paragraph: The evidence that Al Qaeda's branch in Yemen had a role in the failed Christmas Day bombing of an American passenger jet has led some to declare that Yemen is the new front in the war against the terrorist organization. But the truth is, Yemen has been a front in that war since at least Oct. 12, 2000, when Al Qaeda blew up the Navy destroyer Cole, killing 17 American sailors, in the port of Aden. The explosives for the bombing were bought in Yemen. And the attackers and their accomplices were predominantly Yemenis. Indeed, after the attack, terrorists in Qaeda camps in Afghanistan would march and chant, ''We, the Yemenis, destroyed the Cole.'' As the F.B.I. case agent for the Cole investigation from 2000 to 2005, I spent years with colleagues in Yemen hunting down those responsible, and we unraveled an entire Qaeda network in the country.
abstract: Former FBI special agent Ali H Soufan dismisses idea, prompted by Christmas Day bomb plot on Northwest Airlines jet, that Yemen is 'new' front in war on terrorism, insisting that it has been refuge for terrorists since at least Oct 12, 2000, when Al Qaeda blew up Navy destroyer Cole; recalls finding extremely capable Yemeni officials in law enforcement and intelligence who were dedicated to stopping Qaeda, but holds that granting of clemency to Cole bombers injured relationship with US; urges Yemen to signal its sincerity in fight against terrorism by ensuring that Cole bombers are brought to justice (M)
headline: Scenes From the War on Terrorism in Yemen

snippet: Ms. Carroll is widely credited with having blazed the trail for legions of female stand-up comics who came after her.
lead_paragraph: Jean Carroll, a comedian of the 1940s and '50s whose ready wit, impeccable timing and unorthodox blend of glamour and humor made her one of the first female stars of mainstream stand-up comedy, died at a hospital in White Plains on Jan. 1. She was 98 and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y. The death was confirmed by her daughter, Helen Tunick.
headline: Jean Carroll, 98, Is Dead; Blended Wit and Beauty

snippet: With companies sometimes receiving hundreds of applications for a single job, it is becoming more common for hiring managers to conduct initial screening interviews over the phone.
lead_paragraph: With companies sometimes receiving hundreds of applications for a single job, it is becoming more common for hiring managers to conduct initial screening interviews over the phone. This saves them considerable time and money -- especially if a candidate lives out of town. Don't take these interviews lightly. ''It is important to prepare for a telephone interview just as you would for a regular interview,'' said Alison Doyle, a job search specialist for About.com, which is owned by The New York Times Company.
headline: When the First Interview Is a Phone Call

snippet: HARTMAN--Helene, affectionately known to friends and family as Chickie, lost her courageous battle with cancer on Sunday, December 27, 2009. She died peacefully at her home surrounded by her family. A graduate of Woodmere Academy and Bennington...
lead_paragraph: HARTMAN--Helene, affectionately known to friends and family as Chickie, lost her courageous battle with cancer on Sunday, December 27, 2009. She died peacefully at her home surrounded by her family. A graduate of Woodmere Academy and Bennington College, she also received an MA in Education. She is survived by her loving husband and partner of over 53 years Bill Hartman, her adoring children Peter Hartman, Valerie Hartman Levy, Jeannine Bartow Hartman and Jeff Levy, her four grandchildren, Haley Hartman, Charlie, Eli and Cate Levy and her brother, Robert Friedman. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, January 10th at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in Chickie's name to The American Cancer Society or Calvery Hospital Hospice.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, HELENE

snippet: Food lovers no longer have to trade great meals for good weather in this sun-kissed American playground.
lead_paragraph: OCEAN swims, Ocean Drive, Art Deco, Art Basel, palms and pulchritude: these are what draw the crowds to Miami. But not me -- at least not anymore. When I go back, it will be for the ''Pop-Tarts.'' They're a new addition to the menu at Michael's Genuine Food & Drink, which started serving brunch -- and thus the Pop-Tarts -- in late October. And they're not, of course, the supermarket variety. They're a proper pastry chef's riff on those childhood favorites, miniaturized and so adorably dimpled on the edges that I wasn't sure whether to eat or cuddle with them. I opted for eating, trying both the gooey blackberry and the sunny yuzu. Sometimes, but not that day, Michael's serves Nutella-flavored ones, too. I'm checking airfares as I type.
abstract: Frank Bruni Choice Tables column lauds improvements to restaurant scene in Miami, which is attracting new star chefs thanks, in part, to 2007 opening of Michael's in Miami Design District; reviews several new restaurants; photos; map (M)

snippet: The prewar jewel of the Mediterranean has reclaimed its glamour with open-air bars and restaurants and luxury resorts.
lead_paragraph: IT was a peaceful Sunday evening in September, and the sun was casting a reddish glow on the nearby ramparts and ruins perched above the Mediterranean. Below, a yacht filled with bikini-clad women sped into Byblos's famed harbor while the skipper, outfitted in gold aviator shades, squawked the horn for no apparent reason. ''Everyone wants to show off their multimillion-dollar boat,'' said Ziad Baz, the owner of the harborside fish restaurant Bab El Mina, as he puffed on a Cuban cigar and shook his head at the glitzy display of wealth.
abstract: Lionel Beehner travel article on re-emergence of Byblos, Lebanon, as jewel of Mediterranean tourist industry; photo; map (M)

snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been raising money for an American pavilion at the 2010 fair.
lead_paragraph: In the hectic last week before she became secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton squeezed in a Bon Jovi benefit concert in New York, part of a frantic effort to pay off the debt from her presidential campaign. No sooner had she arrived at the State Department than Mrs. Clinton discovered she needed to start raising money all over again. This time, the cash-starved beneficiary was not her own campaign but the United States, which needed $61 million to finance the construction of a national pavilion at a world's fair in Shanghai. Under federal law, no public money could be used for the project. And Mrs. Clinton, as a federal official, could no longer solicit private financial donations herself.
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has raised close to $54 million of $61 million needed for United States pavilion at Shanghai Expo; federal law prohibits using public money on project; Clinton turned to well-established network of fundraisers to meet ambitious fund-raising goal in barely nine months; government lawyers imposed strict limits on kinds of calls and contacts Clinton could make; US is on track to open 60,000-square-foot pavilion; photo (M)
headline: For Shanghai Fair, World-Famous Fund-Raiser Comes Through

snippet: Against some odds, Crosby Street has managed its revitalization without losing its character.
lead_paragraph: AT 11:30 on a Friday morning in December, SoHo was teeming. On Broadway, Topshop overflowed with the aggressively chic; getting to the shoe racks at Bloomingdale's required at least one strategic hip-check; at Uniqlo, there were more people poring over the skinny jeans and affordable cashmere than there are gulls above a successful trawler. And never mind the sidewalk; it was an impossible-to-navigate sea.
abstract: Peace and solitude are attributes of Crosby Street, quiet pocket on eastern side of Cast-Iron Historic district in Manhattan's trendy SoHo neighborhood; while longtime residents see harbingers of change around them, for now Crosby is their little residential secret hidden between commercial boulevards; photos (M)
headline: A Quiet Pocket of SoHo

snippet: President Obama and Thomas H. Kean on the attempted Christmas Day bombing of a passenger jet over Detroit.
lead_paragraph: ''A systemic failure has occurred, and I consider that totally unacceptable.'' --President Obama, on security lapses before the attempted Christmas Day bombing of a passenger jet over Detroit. ''Think of what it took for the father, one of the most respected bankers in Nigeria, to walk into the American embassy and turn in his own son. The father's a hero. His visit by itself should have been enough to set off all kinds of alarms.'' --Thomas H. Kean, chairman of the 9/11 commission, on Alhaji Umaru Mutallab, whose son is charged with trying to blow up an American jetliner.
headline: QUOTATIONS OF THE WEEK

snippet: Men marked the last 10 years of television less as hellions or healers than as analysands  fragile bullies who recognized they were damaged and sought help.
lead_paragraph: THE decade opened with an alpha male in a psychiatrist's office and closed with an alpha male committing himself to a psychiatric institution. From ''The Sopranos'' to ''House,'' men marked the last 10 years of television less as hellions or healers than as analysands -- fragile bullies who recognized they were damaged and sought help. The 21st century was ushered in by a He Decade: 10 years of men gazing at their navels.
