snippet: Northwestern and Loyola are off to their best starts in basketball since the 1960s, but DePaul continues a 20-game slide.
lead_paragraph: The stretch between Christmas and New Year's yielded some highs and lows in local college basketball. Northwestern (11-2 before Saturday's game against Michigan State) cracked the national rankings for the first time since 1969, reaching No. 25 in the Associated Press poll. Nearby Loyola was off to a 10-2 start, racking up 10 wins before January for the first time since 1966.
headline: Loyola and Northwestern Shine, but DePaul Keeps Struggling

snippet: A talent discovered on YouTube has navigated the path of a tween idol. Four singles from his debut release reached the Billboard Top 100, and he has been taken under the wing of the singer Usher.

snippet: Steve Pincock, the trainer, said Coach Mike Leach ordered a receiver locked in a dark place after a concussion.
lead_paragraph: A Texas Tech athletic trainer said he was told by the fired coach Mike Leach to lock wide receiver Adam James in the dark after doctors determined that he had a concussion, according to an affidavit released Saturday by the university. In a Dec. 21 interview with a university investigative attorney looking into James's treatment, Steve Pincock, Texas Tech's head football trainer, said he told James he was sorry about placing him inside an equipment shed on Dec. 17 near the practice field. According to the affidavit, Pincock also said he was not aware that any other player had ever been treated in such a manner.
abstract: TRAINER FAULTS TREATMENT OF PLAYER AT TEX
headline: Trainer Faults Treatment Of Player at Texas Tech

snippet: A love of chocolate leads to a shop that is the hub of community.
lead_paragraph: EVERY morning at 6:30 a.m., as sure as the ebb of the Cape Cod tides, the rise of the sun and the four phases of the moon, the front door at the Hot Chocolate Sparrow is unlocked, and the regulars -- George Malloy, Bill von Thaden, Bart Randall, Jaan Vari, Bruce Bierhans -- hurry in from the cold and the dark for their morning coffees.
abstract: Hot Chocolate Sparrow, Cape Cod chocolate and coffee shop, has become year-round gathering place for residents; owner Marjorie Sparrow says she has had many offers to franchise business but turned them down because she and her husband Bob wanted to build small respectable business that could help put their children through college; photos (M)
headline: A Coffee Shop That Is So Much More

The Jets boast the N.F.L.'s top-ranked rushing offense (166.6 yards per game) and two capable backs in Thomas Jones (1,324 yards, 12 touchdowns, 1 Pro Bowl snub) and Shonn Greene (478 yards, 2 touchdowns). snippet: An article in some editions last Sunday about Urban Meyer's announcement that he was resigning as the University of Florida football coach misidentified the university of Houston Nutt, one of the coaches who reacted to the news. It is the University...
lead_paragraph: An article in some editions last Sunday about Urban Meyer's announcement that he was resigning as the University of Florida football coach misidentified the university of Houston Nutt, one of the coaches who reacted to the news. It is the University of Mississippi -- not the University of Arkansas, which is where he coached from 1998 to 2007. (Meyer later announced he would take an indefinite leave of absence instead of resigning.)
abstract: Correction of Dec 27, 2009, article about Urban Meyer's announcement that he is resigning as University of Florida football coach

snippet: Illegal at 13, Ivy League at 18, and then . . . caught.
lead_paragraph: IN lyrical passages of ''This Side of Paradise,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald's young alter ego, Amory Blaine, is awed by the ''great dreaming spires'' of Princeton and its ''lazy beauty, its half-grasped significance, the wild moonlight revel of the rushes.'' Three generations later, Harold Fernandez was no less awed by the castle-like dormitories, the teeming libraries, the hoary traditions. But Harold Fernandez was different from most freshmen. Amory Blaine had been to prep school, and his mother, though not of the privileged class, had raised him to appreciate the treasures of Western culture. Harold had been raised in the streets of Medellín, Colombia, listening to tango and salsa lyrics that spoke of the harsh local realities of violence, drugs and prison. His American schooling was in a gritty factory town, West New York, N.J.
abstract: Profile of Dr Harold A Fernandez, now cardiac surgeon but once illegal alien who entered Princeton using fake green card and Social Security number; smuggled into Florida as child on boat crowded with illegal immigrants, Hernandez received straight A's his first semester but always feared that his secret would come out; Princeton professor and university president helped Fernandez and family attain legal residency; photos (M)
headline: An Undocumented Princetonian

snippet: Stores have long used sales and demographic information to better aim their goods at customers. But retailers now have access to a vast trove of digital data  and better tools to make sense of it.
lead_paragraph: MOST people think of the grand challenges in computing as big science projects, like simulating nuclear explosions or protein folding. But with the holiday shopping season just ended, consider another: retail marketing. Retailing is emerging as a real-world incubator for testing how computer firepower and smart software can be applied to social science -- in this case, how variables like household economics and human behavior affect shopping.
abstract: Steve Lohr Unboxed column reports experts say retailers have long been sifting through sales and demographic information, but what is changing is rapid surge in amount and types of digital data that they can now tap and improved computing tools to try to make sense of it; photos (M)
headline: A Data Explosion Remakes Retailing

snippet: Setbacks in its nuclear program and protests in the streets are making Iran’s leaders vulnerable to strong new sanctions, the Obama administration says.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama faces pressure to back up his year-end ultimatum for diplomatic progress with Iran, the administration says that domestic unrest and signs of unexpected trouble in Tehran's nuclear program make its leaders particularly vulnerable to strong and immediate new sanctions. The long-discussed sanctions would initiate the latest phase in a strategy to force Iran to comply with United Nations demands to halt production of nuclear fuel. It comes as the administration has completed a fresh review of Iran's nuclear progress.
abstract: Obama administration officials believe Iran's leaders are vulnerable to strong and immediate new sanctions over country's nuclear program; Pres Obama faces pressure to back up his year-end ultimatum for diplomatic progress with Iran; strategists see opportunity amid domestic unrest and signs of unexpected trouble in its program to produce nuclear fuel; want to focus sanctions in Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which has played crucial role in repression of antigovernment demonstrators since disputed presidential election; China and Russia have been reluctant to endorse sanctions and could resist move; photo (M)
headline: U.S. SEES WINDOW TO PRESSURE IRAN ON NUCLEAR FUEL

snippet: The city of Van in far eastern Turkey is famous for its Armenian ruins, stunning scenery and rare white cats -- and terrific breakfast-only restaurants featuring earthy cheeses and delectable local honey. But travelers to Istanbul don't have to...
lead_paragraph: The city of Van in far eastern Turkey is famous for its Armenian ruins, stunning scenery and rare white cats -- and terrific breakfast-only restaurants featuring earthy cheeses and delectable local honey. But travelers to Istanbul don't have to venture nearly 900 miles eastward to sample this authentic regional specialty. Locals trudging the hills of Beyoglu after a night at the clubs have long found that the Van Kahvalti Evi, or Van Breakfast House, in Cihangir (Defterdar Yokusu 52a; 90-212-293-6437) is just the ticket to banish those morning-after aches.
headline: Istanbul: Where Breakfast Is King

snippet: Steve Pincock, the trainer, said Coach Mike Leach ordered a receiver locked in a dark place after a concussion.
lead_paragraph: A Texas Tech athletic trainer said he was told by the fired coach Mike Leach to lock wide receiver Adam James in the dark after doctors determined that he had a concussion, according to an affidavit released Saturday by the university. In a Dec. 21 interview with a university investigative attorney looking into James's treatment, Steve Pincock, Texas Tech's head football trainer, said he told James he was sorry about placing him inside an equipment shed on Dec. 17 near the practice field. According to the affidavit, Pincock also said he was not aware that any other player had ever been treated in such a manner.
abstract: TRAINER FAULTS TREATMENT OF PLAYER AT TEX
headline: Trainer Faults Treatment Of Player at Texas Tech

snippet: Northwestern and Loyola are off to their best starts in basketball since the 1960s, but DePaul continues a 20-game slide.
lead_paragraph: The stretch between Christmas and New Year's yielded some highs and lows in local college basketball. Northwestern (11-2 before Saturday's game against Michigan State) cracked the national rankings for the first time since 1969, reaching No. 25 in the Associated Press poll. Nearby Loyola was off to a 10-2 start, racking up 10 wins before January for the first time since 1966.
headline: Loyola and Northwestern Shine, but DePaul Keeps Struggling

snippet: In academe, sustainability can have as much to do with social science as science science.
lead_paragraph: MOST people see sustainability as pertaining to the physical environment, and the need to preserve it for coming generations. But in academe, sustainability can have as much to do with social science as science science. Goucher College, the liberal arts college in Baltimore, is extending the concept: to preserving the traditional values, as well as the arts, dress, customs and cuisines, of communities threatened by globalization and modernization, whether inner-city neighborhoods or third-world villages. Goucher calls it cultural sustainability, and is offering a Master of Arts.
abstract: Goucher College in Baltimore is offering Master of Arts in cultural sustainability, described as concept of preserving traditional values, arts and customs of communities threatened by globalization and modernization; students will work on projects in US and overseas starting in current semester; photo (M)
headline: A Step Beyond Anthropology

snippet: For China, India, Indonesia and Brazil, which have more than 40 percent of the world’s people, the decade was one of solid economic growth.
lead_paragraph: IT may not feel that way right now, but the last 10 years may go down in world history as a big success. That idea may be hard to accept in the United States. After all, it was the decade of 9/11, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the financial crisis, all dramatic and painful events. But in economic terms, at least, the decade was a remarkably good one for many people around the globe. The raging economic growth rates of China and India are well known, though their rise is part of a broader trend in the economic development of poorer countries. Ideals of prosperity, freedom and the rule of law have probably never been more resonant globally than they've been over the last 10 years, even if practice often falls short. And for all of the anticapitalistic rhetoric that has emerged from the financial crisis, national leaders around the world are embracing the commercialization of their economies.
abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View column contends for much of world, past 10 years has been big economic success; holds steady economic growth is underreported news story; points out it is easy to neglect underlying forces that improve life in small, hard-to-observe ways, culminating in important changes; drawing (M)
headline: For Much of the World, A Fruitful Decade

snippet: WITTEK--Seymour, 88, on December 30, 2009. Devoted son and husband, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, loyal friend. He lived every day to the fullest. In April 1943, Coast Guardsman Wittek volunteered to extinguish a fire aboard the...
lead_paragraph: WITTEK--Seymour, 88, on December 30, 2009. Devoted son and husband, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, loyal friend. He lived every day to the fullest. In April 1943, Coast Guardsman Wittek volunteered to extinguish a fire aboard the S.S. El Estero in New York Harbor, thereby averting disaster. 65 years later, in the presence of his proud family, he was awarded a Coast Guard commendation for bravery on the U.S.S. Intrepid. Seymour's wide range of passions included Yiddishkeit, history and politics, the Coast Guard and the sea, the Yankees and NYC; he remained active in his temple and as a volunteer into his 88th year. Proud lifelong liberal. Seymour was a man of integrity and compassion who touched and inspired many. He will be sorely missed.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTEK, SEYMOUR

snippet: In the last decade, the technology of moviemaking has changed radically. You can even pull a film out of a pocket.
lead_paragraph: HOW much our world of moving-image entertainment has changed in the past decade! We now live in a world of the 24-Hour Movie, one that plays anytime and anywhere you want (and sometimes whether you want it to or not). It's a movie we can access at home by pressing a few buttons on the remote (and agreeing to pay more for it than you might at the local video store) or with a few clicks of the mouse. The 24-Hour Movie now streams instead of unspools, filling our screens with images that, more and more, have been created algorithmically rather than photographically. And yet how little our world of moving-image entertainment has changed! On April 14, 1896, The New York Times ran an article with the exciting if cryptic headline ''Edison's Latest Triumph.'' The triumph was the Vitascope, a machine that ''projects upon a large area of canvas groups that appear to stand forth from the canvas, and move with great facility and agility, as though actuated by separate impulses.'' A proprietor of the music hall where the Vitascope was shown off said this machine would reproduce ''scenes from various successful plays and operas of the season, and well-known statesmen and celebrities,'' adding, ''No other manager in this city will have the right to exhibit the Vitascope.''
abstract: Manohla Dargis article on how technology has affected movies; effects of television, digital vs film and new movie Avatar discussed; photos, drawing (L)
headline: Floating In the Digital Experience

snippet: Pam Liebman, the Corcoran Group real estate firm’s chief executive, spends much of her weekend negotiating the menu to satisfy the preferences of her daughters.
lead_paragraph: As some New Yorkers devote their Sundays to navigating open houses and negotiating on prices, Pam Liebman, president and chief executive of the Corcoran Group real estate brokerage firm, is preoccupied with other types of mediation. Ms. Liebman, 47, and her husband, Michael, 47, a chiropractor, are negotiating the food preferences of their two daughters at home in Warren, N.J. CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY WAKE UP, WORK OUT Around 8 o'clock. I struggle with whether I'm going to leave the house and go to the gym or read part of the paper. As soon as I start reading the paper and have my coffee, it gets delayed. I always go to the gym. I like an hour-and-a-half workout. I like to get there at the latest 9, but I try to get there at 8:30 a.m. I'm not a big gym talker. I just like to get my workout done and get out.
abstract: Pam Liebman, president and chief executive of Corcoran Group real estate brokerage, describes typical Sunday routine; photo (M)
headline: No Work or Naps, and Lots on the Menu

snippet: Vermont calls to mind some vivid associations: maple syrup, progressive politics, cheese. Laini Fondiller has brought two of the three together with Lazy Lady Farm. Taking inspiration from the talk radio she listens to while making cheese from goat...
lead_paragraph: Vermont calls to mind some vivid associations: maple syrup, progressive politics, cheese. Laini Fondiller has brought two of the three together with Lazy Lady Farm. Taking inspiration from the talk radio she listens to while making cheese from goat and cow milk in her off-the-grid facility, Fondiller has sent out offerings with names like Tomme Delay (a riff on French tomme-style cheese), Barick Obama (a square cheese from 2004, named after the young state senator gave his speech at the Democratic National Convention) and Fil-a-Buster (a hefty wheel banded with spruce). The Ben & Jerry's flavor Imagine Whirled Peace might make for a cute take on a bumper sticker for the state's rusty Saabs, but until Hubby Hubby becomes permanent, Lazy Lady has the leftie-foodie market cornered. People who want to pick up a Crumb Cake goat cheese this month will be out of luck. Wait, you mean cheeses have a season? Yes: Even Barack couldn't get a Barick from June to October. As the organic milk from her goats naturally tapers off in the winter -- ''The goats just began to collect unemployment as of last Friday,'' Fondiller e-mailed me on Dec. 15 -- she mixes it with organic milk from her neighbors' Holsteins and Jerseys to create cheeses like Bipartisan (cow with goat in the middle), moving into all-cow before phasing back into goat in the spring. For a few weeks in the fall of 2008, she used the dregs of a vat of cow milk to make Palin Comparison: ''I said, 'This is where they drug her up from!' ''
abstract: Profile of Laini Fondiller, dairy farmer in Vermont; Fondiller playfully twists names of politicians to come up with original brands for her goat and cow milk cheeses; recipes; photos (M)
headline: A Whey With Words

snippet: Years out, alumni turn to their alma maters for job-hunt help.
lead_paragraph: SIX years ago, as a senior at the University of Colorado, Boulder, Meg Goodwin was motivated in her job search by social anxiety as much as anything else. Her friends had positions lined up, so she wanted one, too. She went to the career counseling center and signed up for interviews for 10 different jobs, none of which she particularly wanted. Now a financial planner, Ms. Goodwin is still not sure she ever figured out what she wanted to do. As the employment rate steadily slipped and her line of work became increasingly inhospitable, she, like many alumni around the country, has returned to her university's career center to begin the search process all over again. ''It's a humbling experience to go back to your old school and be asking for help,'' says Ms. Goodwin, who is now considering a career in corporate education.
abstract: Traditionally, university career counselors do not serve graduates 6 or 12 months after they have finished college; however, with influx of requests from alumni who are now or fear they soon will be unemployed, career services offices have become hub for disenchanted graduates; some colleges charge alumni for counseling sessions, while others are free; photos (M)

snippet: Of the 24 cabinet nominees made by President Hamid Karzai, 17 were rejected and 7 approved, a signal that he cannot count on Parliament for support.
lead_paragraph: In a clear signal to President Hamid Karzai that he cannot count on Parliament for support, lawmakers resoundingly rejected most of his nominees for cabinet posts and expressed discontent with the candidates' competence. Of Mr. Karzai's 24 cabinet nominees, 17 were rejected and 7 approved. Of those who received votes of confidence, all but one are currently cabinet ministers.
headline: Afghan Parliament Rejects Most of Karzai's Nominees for Cabinet Positions

lead_paragraph: VAN DOREN--Marie Antoinette, died of cancer December 30 in New York City. She is survived by her husband Peter and brothers Jean and Jacques Cornet and sister Helene Clarke. Manie was a 1951 graduate of the Sacred Heart School at Noroton and spent much of her working life in fashion, including two years as a volunteer at the Costume Department of the Smithsonian. From 1988-2000 she was the President of The Woman's Exchange in Manhattan. A memorial Mass will be said at St. Vincent Ferrer at 3pm Thursday, January 21.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DOREN, MARIE

snippet: On Dec. 19, the couple married at their Fort Greene loft, followed by a reception for 60.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORKERS have a talent for breathing new life into objects left on curbs or stoops. One person's castoff is another person's coffee table. A pile of books that somebody leaves for the garbage truck can become somebody else's library. Elizabeth Cronise was thinking something along these lines when, in August 2008, she spotted a leather bracelet in her bicycle basket. How it got there remains a mystery, but pondering its meaning seemed more intriguing than finding its owner.

snippet: With nearly 300 companies on its roster, the Silicon Valley Leadership Group stands out as a small island of ideological diversity in a sea of partisan polarization.
lead_paragraph: The Silicon Valley Leadership Group represents business interests in a region known for being on the leading edge of innovation. But when it comes to politics, the group is decidedly retro, a throwback to the days when there was a viable center in California's civic affairs. With nearly 300 companies on its roster, from Accenture to Yahoo, the group stands out as a small island of ideological diversity in a sea of partisan polarization.
headline: To-Do List Grows For Leadership Group

snippet: The arrest of Carlos Beltrán Leyva comes weeks after his brother Arturo, reputed chief of the Beltrán Leyva Cartel, was killed in a shootout.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican police have captured a man suspected of being a drug lord, Carlos Beltrán Leyva, just weeks after his even more powerful brother was killed in a shootout with troops -- back-to-back victories in President Felipe Calderón's drug war. The Public Safety office said in a statement Saturday night that Mr. Beltrán Leyva was arrested in Culiacán, the capital of Sinaloa State, where he and several of his brothers were born and were said to have started their gang.
abstract: Mexican police in Culiacan capture suspected drug lord Carlos Beltran Leyva, whose brother Arturo was killed in shootout with troops in Cuernavaca; another brother Alfredo was arrested in January 2008, while fourth brother Mario remains at large as one of country's most wanted suspected drug lords (M)
headline: Mexican Police Capture Cartel Official, Brother of Slain Boss

snippet: The first decade of the new century marked no great epoch of the Broadway musical, but there have been occasional, heartening sparks of aesthetic regeneration.
lead_paragraph: JUDGED from the long view of history, the Broadway musical's rise, reign and fall appear to have taken place in a flash. This American-born art form reached its artistic peak in the 1940s and began a slide toward senescence a mere two decades later. But take a stroll through Times Square today, and a different point of view asserts itself. The tourists thronging the area aren't coming for the lawn chairs, after all, or the peculiar chain stores devoted to candy brands. The primary business that makes this clogged artery the tourist heart of the city is theater, and the musical remains its driving force. Stand in the lobby as audiences emerge from ''Wicked'' or ''Billy Elliot,'' and you surf a tide of happy babble. The theatergoers clogging the tchotchke dispensaries in the Gershwin or the Imperial Theaters may well look back on the experience with the same ineffable glow that is driving audiences of another generation to the revival of ''South Pacific.''
headline: Cue the Chorus: The Musical Endures

snippet: We are a group of women verging on old, old age. We have known each other for more than 40 years and are closing in on 80. We are beyond face-lifts and Botox. Most of us will not opt for hip replacements or assisted living (yet). We travel around the...
lead_paragraph: We are a group of women verging on old, old age. We have known each other for more than 40 years and are closing in on 80. We are beyond face-lifts and Botox. Most of us will not opt for hip replacements or assisted living (yet). We travel around the world, to Rome, France and the Galápagos. We garden and paint our walls. We do yoga and swim at the Y. We go to the theater and the opera. We volunteer time and energy to community services: housing help, food pantries, the historical society. Our icebergs loom offshore, but we're not dead yet. We are survivors. Five of us have survived our husbands and the grief and trials of widowhood. We rely on one another for medical referrals (most of our doctors have retired), handymen, plumbers and tree men. We have survived knee replacements, cancer and major surgery. We take a ton of pills just for maintenance.
headline: Asking 'How Are You?' And Hearing Grumbles

snippet: The number of Americans reporting food stamps as their only income soared 50 percent over the past two years.
lead_paragraph: After an improbable rise from the Bronx projects to a job selling Gulf Coast homes, Isabel Bermudez lost it all to an epic housing bust -- the six-figure income, the house with the pool and the investment property. Now, as she papers the county with résumés and girds herself for rejection, she is supporting two daughters on an income that inspires a double take: zero dollars in monthly cash and a few hundred dollars in food stamps.
headline: Living on Nothing but Food Stamps

snippet: HOME equity lines of credit, once a staple of home finance, have been fading from view, and not only because securing credit is generally more difficult. As borrowers also grow more fiscally conservative, industry experts say, many are becoming...
lead_paragraph: HOME equity lines of credit, once a staple of home finance, have been fading from view, and not only because securing credit is generally more difficult. As borrowers also grow more fiscally conservative, industry experts say, many are becoming reluctant to take on these second mortgages. Helocs, as they're known in the industry, are typically open-ended revolving credit products, with interest rates pegged to the prime lending rate, which banks offer their best customers.
abstract: Mortgages column on bleak outlook for home equity lines of credit, once staple of home finance; even though home prices have stabilized, fewer people have enough equity in homes to qualify, and many banks continue to be reluctant to offer lines of credit based on home equity; graph of mortgage rates in New York region (M)
headline: A Trickle From the Equity Tap

snippet: Sarah Brooks Barlow and Nicholas James Huston were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. Dr. Christian Isichei, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the restaurant Bubby’s Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Brooks Barlow and Nicholas James Huston were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. Dr. Christian Isichei, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the restaurant Bubby's Brooklyn. The bride, 39, is the chairwoman of the English department at the Little Red School House and Elisabeth Irwin High School, a private school in Manhattan, where she also teaches eighth-grade English and history. She graduated magna cum laude from Occidental College in Los Angeles and received a master's degree in teaching English from Brown.
headline: Sarah Barlow, Nicholas Huston

snippet: <!-- ROBERT H SMITH -->SMITH--Robert H. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the untimely passing of our leader Robert H. Smith (z"l), a towering philanthropist, humanitarian, business leader and...
lead_paragraph: SMITH--Robert H. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the untimely passing of our leader Robert H. Smith (z"l), a towering philanthropist, humanitarian, business leader and advocate for the Jewish people. Bob Smith was vitally involved with The Hebrew University and AFHU for decades, serving as chairman of Hebrew University's Board of Governors and president of AFHU's Washington, DC chapter. He received an honorary doctorate from Hebrew University in 1985. Bob's leadership and support have propelled a transformative vision for sustainable agriculture research at Hebrew University. Recently, the Robert H. Smith Faculty of Agriculture, Food and Environment was renamed in his honor. We extend our utmost sympathies to Bob's beloved wife Clarice, to their children David Bruce Smith and Michelle Smith, to their grandchildren, and to Bob's sister, Arlene R. Kogod. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Michael Federmann, Chairman of the Board of Governors Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University George A. Schieren, Chairman Martin E. Karlinsky, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT H.

snippet: In her kitchen in Larchmont, Valérie Del-Sol Wetterhahn bakes galettes des rois and other European delicacies to make the holidays special for French expatriates and others.
lead_paragraph: THE holiday season spells downtime for many, but not for Valérie Del-Sol Wetterhahn of Bisou and Tartine, a licensed home baker who makes European delicacies for her fellow French expatriates, and other discerning customers, in Larchmont and surrounding towns. No sooner had Ms. Wetterhahn stuck the last meringue mushroom on her last bûche de noël than she was rolling out puff pastry for her first galettes des rois, a confection eaten in the days before and after Epiphany, or Twelfth Night, on Jan. 6, to celebrate the arrival of the three kings bearing gifts for the baby Jesus. ''In France, you can find the galette the very day after Christmas,'' Ms. Wetterhahn said. ''I already have 13 on order, and more to come. The galette is something that everybody loves, not just children.''
headline: Old-World Tradition Lives in Her Kitchen

snippet: Who knew that an advanced degree would be in order for the largely blue-collar construction industry or, in this economy, that it would be in demand?
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to construction, most of us think hammers, nails and concrete. Who knew that an advanced degree would be in order for this largely blue-collar industry or, in this economy, that it would be in demand? In fact, construction administration involves financing (bidding, estimating, cost control), people skills (labor negotiations) and management (project planning). Average salary: a lofty $90,000 in 2008, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And every level of credential, from certificate to Ph.D., is offered at every kind of institution, from Ivy League (Columbia University) to for-profit (University of Phoenix Online).
abstract: Advanced degrees in construction administration, which involves financing, people skills and management, are in demand and offered at every kind of institution; applications at New York University spring master's program are up 33 percent over last year; numbers are even higher for graduate certification program; experts attribute rising interest to federal stimulus program's emphasis on building highways and other infrastructure; photo (M)
headline: Building More Than Resumés

snippet: Robert Wong began his career at 23 as a correctional officer at San Quentin. Now, 27 years later, he is ending it as the acting warden.
lead_paragraph: Robert Wong began his career at 23 as a correctional officer at San Quentin. Now, 27 years later, he is ending it as the acting warden. He oversees 2,000 employees and 5,200 prisoners, including 680 on death row. Few inmates see the bay view that is his paradise. (His words have been edited and condensed.) CAROL POGASH
headline: Giving a Job a New Perspective

snippet: 35 billion: The amount in dollars that Chinese officials misused or embezzled in the first 11 months of 2009, according to a national audit released last week.     The announcement was the latest indication of how widespread corruption has become...
lead_paragraph: 35 billion: The amount in dollars that Chinese officials misused or embezzled in the first 11 months of 2009, according to a national audit released last week. The announcement was the latest indication of how widespread corruption has become among government agencies and how difficult it will be for Beijing to root it out. The audit of nearly 100,000 government departments and state-owned companies found officials engaged in laundering money, issuing fraudulent loans and cheating the government through the sale or purchase of state property. More than 1,000 officials were facing prosecution or disciplinary action as a result of the audits, the government's National Audit Office said.
headline: 35 billion
byline: {"organization"=>"THE NEW YORK TIMES", "original"=>"By THE NEW YORK TIMES", "person"=>[]}

snippet: Soon after the attempted Christmas Day bombing on Northwest Airlines Flight 253, the government announced that it was reviewing airline security measures, particularly on international flights heading toward the United States.      Some of the...
lead_paragraph: Soon after the attempted Christmas Day bombing on Northwest Airlines Flight 253, the government announced that it was reviewing airline security measures, particularly on international flights heading toward the United States. Some of the proposed measures -- including forbidding all movement in the cabin and banning access to all ''personal items'' an hour before landing -- were met with disbelief and consternation among many readers who commented on the Travel section's In Transit blog.

headline: Readers' Comments: Safer Flying

snippet: SMITH--Robert H. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the untimely passing of our leader Robert H. Smith (z"l), a towering philanthropist, humanitarian, business leader and advocate for the Jewish...
lead_paragraph: SMITH--Robert H. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the untimely passing of our leader Robert H. Smith (z"l), a towering philanthropist, humanitarian, business leader and advocate for the Jewish people. Bob Smith was vitally involved with The Hebrew University and AFHU for decades, serving as chairman of Hebrew University's Board of Governors and president of AFHU's Washington, DC chapter. He received an honorary doctorate from Hebrew University in 1985. Bob's leadership and support have propelled a transformative vision for sustainable agriculture research at Hebrew University. Recently, the Robert H. Smith Faculty of Agriculture, Food and Environment was renamed in his honor. We extend our utmost sympathies to Bob's beloved wife Clarice, to their children David Bruce Smith and Michelle Smith, to their grandchildren, and to Bob's sister, Arlene R. Kogod. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Michael Federmann, Chairman of the Board of Governors Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University George A. Schieren, Chairman Martin E. Karlinsky, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT H

snippet: He isn’t a populist. That doesn’t mean he’s not a progressive.
lead_paragraph: There was something discordant, even tinny, about Barack Obama's attempt to castigate Wall Street last month. No doubt the president was trying to acknowledge and channel the resentments in his own party -- and in the country -- when he told CBS's Steve Kroft during a ''60 Minutes'' interview, ''I did not run for office to be helping out a bunch of fat-cat bankers on Wall Street.'' Yet the rhetorical slap felt a little flat. In part it was the oddity of the epithet, a musty Washington cliché that had the effect of making Obama, the most urbane president in a half-century, sound as if he belonged in some black-and-white talkie from the '40s. Why, listen here: I oughtta pound you -- and all your fat-cat pals! But it was also Obama's body language, the dutiful way in which he delivered the line and elaborated on it, that gave the impression of a dapper man trying on an ill-fitting suit. When the president sat down for an amiable conversation with a group of those very same fat cats the next day, it only reinforced the impression among disenchanted Democrats that Obama shows more deference to moneyed interests than he does to liberals.
headline: No-Commoner Obama

snippet: A nonnative fish that consumes the food of other, native fish is unwanted in Michigan, and the state is suing to have waterways shut down.
lead_paragraph: Asian carp, the voracious, nonnative fish whose arrival near Lake Michigan is threatening to cause havoc in the Great Lakes, are now setting off strife on land as well. In an urgent effort to close down Chicago-area passages that could allow the unwanted fish to reach Lake Michigan, the State of Michigan is suing the State of Illinois and other entities that govern the waterways here. Minnesota, Ohio and Wisconsin have filed documents in recent days supporting Michigan's move, and Indiana says it will soon do the same.
headline: Fight Against an Invasive Fish Threatens a Fragile Unity in the Great Lakes

snippet: In an age of digital imagery, one man still earns a living roaming the streets with a vintage camera grafted onto a Polaroid back.
lead_paragraph: FORGET what your parents told you: money does grow on trees. Well, at least for the street photographers who work the crowds around the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, it does. With digital cameras and ink-jet printers powered by car batteries, they churn out images at about $10 a pop. Arrivistes, as far as Louis Mendes is concerned. Where is the skill in setting a camera to ''automatic'' and pushing a button? Where is the permanence in a shot printed with no-name ink on no-name paper? Where is the craft?

snippet: An architectural exhibition in New Haven explores the impact of the Yale Las Vegas Studio and the work of Venturi Scott Brown and Associates.
lead_paragraph: IT'S a rare architecture exhibition that can be described as ''fun for the whole family.'' But the current offering at the Yale School of Architecture's gallery deserves the plaudit. ''What We Learned: The Yale Las Vegas Studio and the Work of Venturi Scott Brown and Associates,'' which was reviewed in The New York Times on Dec. 23 by Nicolai Ouroussoff, takes a stab at decoding the legacy of Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, Philadelphia-based architects known as much for their ideas as for their buildings. Those ideas include referencing pop culture icons, from Andy Warhol to McDonald's, in otherwise ''serious'' architecture.
headline: A View of Modernism Through a Vegas Lens

snippet: <!-- MILES S PENDLETON -->PENDLETON--Miles S., Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel...
lead_paragraph: PENDLETON--Miles S., Jr., known as Kim, 70, a retired U. S. Foreign Service officer, died December 19, 2009, at his home in Washington, DC. The cause was Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. In his 30-year career he served in Tel Aviv, Bujumbura, Brussels, London, Paris and Washington, DC. In retirement he was active in the Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Research Consortium and The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. Born in Montclair, NJ on March 22, 1939, Kim Pendleton grew up in Andover, MA, graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, and Yale College, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, and received a Masters in Public Administration from Harvard University in 1967 and a diploma from the National War College in 1980. He was the son of Miles S. Pendleton and Lucille Bond Pendleton. He taught in Ghana from 1962 to 1964. He joined the U.S. Foreign Service in 1967 was assigned to Tel Aviv, where he served as a vice consul and staff assistant to the ambassador, Walworth Barbour, followed by a tour in Bujumbura during the ethnic strife between Tutsis and Hutus in 1972. In Washington DC, he served as a staff officer on the Secretariat Staff, going on several of the Kissinger shuttle flights, and then special assistant to Robert S Ingersoll, the Deputy Secretary of State, 1974-1976. From 1979 to 1985 he served as Deputy Director of the Office of Northern European Affairs during the Falkland Islands War in the spring of 1982, Director of the Office of Israel and Arab-Israel Affairs during the Israeli Lebanon incursion later in 1982, and Executive Assistant to Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. He was Minister Counselor for Political Affairs in London from 1985 to 1989 and Paris from 1989 to 1993. Known for his ready smile and white hair, he surrounded himself with friends, loved conversation, and treated anyone he met with consideration and kindness. Courageous and honest in all matters, but particularly in facing cancer, he possessed a keen, independent mind and was passionate for the causes he supported including the schools he loved. He loved to be in Maine, to sail, and to read The New York Times and The Washington Post. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Elisabeth Morgan Pendleton, his son Nathaniel Pendleton of Washington, DC, his daughter Constance Pendleton and son-in-law Jason Gross of Washington DC and a grandson, a brother, Lea Pendleton of Marblehead, MA and a sister Lissa Pendleton of Westford, MA. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 14 at 11am at St Alban's Episcopal Church, 3001 Wisconsin Ave, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Trustees of Phillips Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810-4161 www.andover.edu or the Washington Hospital Center Foundation 110 Irving Street NW, EB 1001, Washington DC 20010-2975 for the benefit of the Washington Cancer Institute, www.whcenter.org/foundation
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDLETON, MILES S.

snippet: <!-- DAVID  LEVINE -->LEVINE--David. He has given us everything we need. A way to start a painting, a way to lose a painting in order to rediscover it, an approach to painting that allows us to live without ego, an example of how a true artist lives...
lead_paragraph: LEVINE--David. He has given us everything we need. A way to start a painting, a way to lose a painting in order to rediscover it, an approach to painting that allows us to live without ego, an example of how a true artist lives a life in art, a way of making art social, a way of finding your subject. We will miss his rich instruction to enjoy the medium, but we will always have his voice saying, "Play, have fun." The Painting Group
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DAVID

lead_paragraph: A Maplewood Township ambulance collided with a passenger car this morning around 10:30 a.m. The ambulance was heading back to the firehouse on Dunnell Road when it collided with the car at the intersection of Springfield Avenue and Boyden Avenue. lead_paragraph: A recent article in The Chicago Tribune described a continuing debate in business schools over whether their enrollees should be regarded as "customers" rather than as traditional students. And does the issue reflect broader issues in higher education?

snippet: On the final day of the regular season, seven A.F.C. teams are alive for the two wild-card spots. In the N.F.C. most of the seeds are up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: Update | 11:28 p.m. On the final day of the regular season, seven A.F.C. teams were alive for the two wild-card spots. In the N.F.C. most of the seeds were up for grabs. At the end of the day, the Vikings had a bye, the Cowboys were N.F.C. East champions, and the Ravens and the Jets had the A.F.C. wild cards. The Fifth Down tracked the results and the changing playoff scenarios as the day went on.
abstract: On the final day of the regular season, seven A.F.C. teams are alive for the two wild-card spots. In the N.F.C. most of the seeds are up for grabs.

snippet: A motel guest in the Florida Keys was arrested for the murder of four family members at Thanksgiving dinner after he was recognized from the show “America’s Most Wanted.”
lead_paragraph: A secretive motel guest in the Florida Keys checked in under a fake name, paid in cash, stockpiled canned food and insisted on cleaning his own room. He even covered his car -- all an effort, the authorities said, to elude the police after he was accused of killing four relatives at Thanksgiving dinner. But the cover of the man, Paul Merhige, was blown when the motel owners recognized him in a preview for the television show ''America's Most Wanted'' on Saturday night.
abstract: Paul Merhige, accused of killing four relatives at Thanksgiving dinner in Jupiter, Fla, is caught while staying at Edgewater Lodge on Long Key; motel owners recognized Merhige after seeing preview for television show America's Most Wanted (S)
headline: Suspect in Family Killing Is Caught

snippet: For a salad to make a meal, it should contain something more substantial, like grains, beans or potatoes, or protein-rich ingredients like cheese, fish or eggs. Poach an egg, place it atop a generous serving of frisée salad tossed with croutons,...
lead_paragraph: For a salad to make a meal, it should contain something more substantial, like grains, beans or potatoes, or protein-rich ingredients like cheese, fish or eggs. Poach an egg, place it atop a generous serving of frisée salad tossed with croutons, herbs and a tart vinaigrette, and you’ve got lunch or a light dinner. A spinach salad with green beans can be transformed into a comforting and nourishing meal when warm potatoes tossed with vinaigrette and feta are added to the mix. I’ve made this mixed-grains salad using both regular brown rice and brown basmati rice. I like the lightness of the basmati brown rice, but I also enjoy the chewiness of regular brown rice.

snippet: In a decade, cellphones have become smart enough to displace P.D.A.’s and threaten landline phones, cameras and GPS devices. What may fall next?
lead_paragraph: What will the mobile phone devour next? It swallowed up the personal digital assistant, the gadget that defined the beginning of the last decade, and is eating through the landline telephone, digital camera, MP3 player and even the wristwatch. The creative destruction has just begun. Investors should heed the mobile phone's Schumpeterian powers. When the century began, bankers ''beamed'' each other information via the now-quaint infrared technology of the Palm Pilot, whose maker had a market value of $92 billion. Palm shifted to mobile phones, but lost 97 percent of its value along the way. That should be a warning to other industries standing in the cellphone's path.
headline: The Smartphone Makes and Breaks

snippet: McGUINNESS--William D.,of Norwalk, CT, age 87, died surrounded by his family on December 15, 2009. Bill was the husband of Catherine (Murphy) McGuinness, who predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Kenneth D. McGuinness, and his wife, Jeanne...
lead_paragraph: McGUINNESS--William D.,of Norwalk, CT, age 87, died surrounded by his family on December 15, 2009. Bill was the husband of Catherine (Murphy) McGuinness, who predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Kenneth D. McGuinness, and his wife, Jeanne Anne Norton of Albany and New York, NY; Monica M. McNally, and her husband, Francis of Lee, NH; Sheila M. Wall, and her husband, Richard of Norwalk, CT and Wm. Danner McGuinness, Jr. and his wife Lorena of Albany, NY, and 11 grandchildren. Mr. McGuinness was born in New York, NY. He graduated from Brooklyn College, NYU and the Harvard AMP Program. He was a WWII veteran, serving in the Battle of the Bulge. He served in various insurance/finance capacities for the following companies: Flintkote, the Port Authority of NYNJ, Exxon and subsidiaries, ultimately retiring in 1985 as Treasurer of Gulf Oil Corporation. He will be remembered for his determination, resiliency, educational patronage and passion. A mass will be held at 11:30am on January 9, 2010 at St. Jerome RC Church, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Running Strong for American Indian Youth at P.O. Box 670, Raton, NM 87740, the Second Genesis Foundation at 8611 Second Ave, Suite 300, Silver Springs, MD 20910, or Connecticut Hospice, 1 Park St., Norwalk, CT 06851. For more information, please visit: www.collinsfh.com.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, WILLIAM D.

snippet: WRUBEL--George Jay, loving husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather. Dr. Wrubel graduated from Union College, subsequently earning a DDS degree from New York University College of Dentistry. He also completed a Post Graduate Periodontics...
lead_paragraph: WRUBEL--George Jay, loving husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather. Dr. Wrubel graduated from Union College, subsequently earning a DDS degree from New York University College of Dentistry. He also completed a Post Graduate Periodontics Program at Veterans Administration Hospital and served as a Captain in the United States Army. Dr. Wrubel was a tireless educator, mentoring numerous students in Periodontics for nearly 48 years at New York University College of Dentistry as well as at Staten Island Hospital, and Seaview Hospital. Additionally, Dr. Wrubel maintained his own private practice in Staten Island, New York for nearly 46 years. He served as the President of the New York section of the American Academy of Oral Medicine and was elected president of the Richmond County Dental Society. He is a Fellow of the American College of Dentists and was also an active member of both the Northeast Society of Periodontics as well as the American Academy of Periodontology. Dr. Wrubel was a former president and member of Congregation B'nai Jeshrun of Staten Island, and also worshipped at Sutton Place Synagogue in Manhattan and Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, NY. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Evelyn Wrubel of Riverdale, NY; his children, Dr. Lee Wrubel and his wife, Michele Wrubel of Westport, CT; Austin Wrubel and his partner Prithvi Kumar of Manhattan and Hartsdale, NY; and Eric Wrubel and his partner Paul Toth of Chappaqua, NY; and his beloved grandchildren, Alec, Brooke, and Olivia. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Manhattan on Tuesday, January 5 with burial at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island. Shiva will be held in both Riverdale, NY and Westport, CT. Dr. Wrubel will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues, patients, friends and all who had the good fortune to have known him.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRUBEL, GEORGE JAY

snippet: Multitouch screens have been a little slower to enter the electronics marketplace than consumers might have hoped. Since Jeff Han presented his multitouch wall at the Technology, Entertainment and Design conference in 2006, we have seen the...
lead_paragraph: Multitouch screens have been a little slower to enter the electronics marketplace than consumers might have hoped. Since Jeff Han presented his multitouch wall at the Technology, Entertainment and Design conference in 2006, we have seen the technology appear in the iPhone, some Android-based smartphones and Hewlett-Packard's TouchSmart countertop computer, but other appearances in consumer electronics have been rare. That might all change soon. Ilya Rosenberg, Ken Perlin and a small team of computer scientists from New York University's Media Research Lab hope to bring a new kind of multitouch to items as diverse as new e-readers and musical instruments with their new company, Touchco.
abstract: Multitouch screens, which have seen limited popularity in devices such as iPhone, may soon have wider application; company Touchco is developing technology that will allow unlimited simultaneous touch points and force-sensitive resistance, creating fluid and versatile experience that critics say current technology lacks; new screens would also be cheaper and use less energy (M)
headline: New Multitouch Screens in the Works

snippet: When kidnappers last week released the hostage Peter Moore an unanswered question remained: What about Alan McMenemy, one of four bodyguards captured along with Mr. Moore?
lead_paragraph: The Iraqi government may be close to a deal with those who took five British men hostage in 2007 that will finally clarify the fate of the last of them, a government spokesman said Sunday. The remains of three were recovered last year; the fourth, Peter Moore, was released alive last week. The British government has long thought the last man, Alan McMenemy, is also dead and has pressed for the return of his remains.
abstract: Iraqi government nears deal with those who took five British men hostage in 2007 that will clarify their fate; remains of three bodyguards were recovered last year and fourth man Peter Moore was released alive last week; British government believes Alan McMenemy is also dead and has pressed for return of his remains; all were believed held by Shiite militia League of the Righteous, or Asaib al-Haq; Iraq reportedly agrees to help bring civil lawsuits against employees of Blackwater Worldwide, renamed Xe Services, over September 2007 shooting in Baghdad that left 17 Iraqis dead and about 20 wounded (M)
headline: Iraq Says Deal Is Near On the Last Of 5 Hostages

snippet: The Cowboys set up a rematch with the Eagles in the first round of the playoffs at Cowboys Stadium after their third consecutive victory and second straight shutout.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Cowboys erased a reputation of late-season flops and maligned performances Sunday, capturing the National Football Conference East title with a 24-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles at Cowboys Stadium. Dallas's win set up a rematch against Philadelphia in the wild-card round of the playoffs here Saturday night, with the Cowboys as the No. 3 seed, the Eagles as No. 6. Dallas can certainly enter the postseason claiming it is the hottest team in the conference, even in the wake of the Vikings' dismantling of the Giants.
abstract: *Dallas Cowboys defeat Philadelphia Eagles, 24-0, to win National Football Conference East division title and advance to playoffs; photo (M)

snippet: This is the busiest time of the year for stores purveying charms, amulets and other items for Afro-Caribbean religions and occult practices.
lead_paragraph: Cecilia Oliver was having a problem with her lover and needed some help. ''He's being resistant,'' she explained. ''I want where he's submissive to me at all times.'' She had come to the Original Products Company, a Bronx emporium where she had heard she could buy the ingredients for a magic charm to put under the insole of her shoe.
abstract: Botanicas in New York City, purveyors of herbs, amulets and other items used in Afro-Caribbean religions and occult practices including Santeria, Voodoo and Wicca, are finding New Year to be their busiest season; customers, infused with spirit of renewal, are searching for ways to improve their lives; photos (M)
headline: At a Botanica, New Year Means Renewal, and Jinx Removal

snippet: Is an Apple tablet the second coming of the iPhone: a device that can do anything, including saving embattled print providers from doom?
lead_paragraph: Last year about this time, I was talking with an executive from Apple about e-readers and print at a conference we were both attending, much of it in the context of the mainstream media's original sin of giving away content if people happened to be reading it in digital form. As we chatted casually over drinks -- he wasn't on the record and wouldn't be even if it would end world hunger, because he works at Apple -- I told him that a workable tablet that featured content that could be priced and sold as an app would fix some of what ailed print. ''What the world is waiting for,'' I keened, ''is a lightweight device that has a backlit, four-color screen big enough to comfortably read on with touch navigation and a wireless connection.''
abstract: Apple is expected to launch version of tablet computer at January 26 event; rumored product, likely to be called iSlate, will cost roughly $800 and begin selling in March; print media companies are betting on technology to help fix industry that is searching for ways to charge for content that its readers have become accustomed to getting for free (M)
headline: A Savior In the Form Of a Tablet

snippet: Alejandro Morales, who was admitted to Bellevue Hospital Center on Sunday, is accused of stabbing Anthony Maldonado in Morningside Heights.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of fatally stabbing a 9-year-old boy in an Upper Manhattan apartment over the weekend has suffered from schizophrenia for many years and was paroled from prison in May after serving five years for assault, according to family members and the police. The man, Alejandro Morales, 25, who was admitted to Bellevue Hospital Center on Sunday, first told investigators that intruders had tried to break into the apartment to rob him and said nothing about the boy, Anthony Maldonado of Palisades Park, N.J., according to a law enforcement official with direct knowledge of the case. Mr. Morales's story shifted a few more times before he admitted that he stabbed the boy, the official said.
abstract: Family members say Alejandro Morales, accused of fatally stabbing 9-year-old Anthony Maldonado in Upper Manhattan (NYC) apartment, has suffered from schizophrenia for many years and was paroled from prison in May 2009 after serving five years for assault; Morales says Maldonado provoked attack; photo (M)
headline: Parolee Held in Boy's Killing Was Mentally Ill, Mother Says

snippet: Provisions in the Senate health care bill, including one that singles out the construction industry for special treatment, are attracting scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Early versions of the Senate's far-reaching health care bill said that small businesses with fewer than 50 workers would not be penalized if they failed to provide insurance. That was before labor unions in the construction industry went to work and persuaded Senate leaders to insert five paragraphs. Their provision, added to the 2,074-page bill at the last minute, singles out the construction industry for special treatment, in a way that benefits union members and contractors who use union labor.
abstract: Last-minute provisions added to Senate's far-reaching health care bill single out construction industry for special treatment, in way that benefits union members and contractors who use union labor; special provisions illustrate difficulty of establishing uniform national requirements in country in which employers have, over decades, devised myriad different arrangements for providing health insurance to employees (M)
headline: In Health Bill For Everyone, Provisions For a Few

snippet: Before the Ravens lost to the Patriots on Oct. 4, their offense was being hailed as nearly the explosive equal of the Patriots', which to that point had struggled. The game was close -- a 27-21 Patriots victory -- but it sent Baltimore into a...
lead_paragraph: Before the Ravens lost to the Patriots on Oct. 4, their offense was being hailed as nearly the explosive equal of the Patriots', which to that point had struggled. The game was close -- a 27-21 Patriots victory -- but it sent Baltimore into a tailspin, largely because of its defense. The Ravens lost three in a row. Their offense has not been the same since, either, scoring big only against leaky defenses like the Lions' and the Bears'. No matter their record, is there any team that makes opponents more nervous in January than the Patriots? New England had looked to be rounding into playoff form, but losing receiver Wes Welker to a season-ending knee injury is devastating. The Ravens can focus on stopping Randy Moss. The Patriots have had problems with their secondary, and the pass rush has been less than effective against elite quarterbacks. If the Patriots can get a lead, Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco will be on the run. Still, this is not the Patriots' best team by a long shot, and even if they get past the Ravens, Indianapolis and San Diego could scorch the secondary.

headline: American Football Conference: Wild-Card Round

snippet: Mr. Haugland was the last surviving member of the six-man crew that sailed on the Kon-Tiki expedition in 1947.
lead_paragraph: Knut Haugland, the last surviving member of the six-man crew that sailed on the Kon-Tiki expedition in 1947, and a leader of the Norwegian resistance who helped carry out one of the most daring acts of sabotage of World War II, died in Oslo on Dec. 25. He was 92. His death was confirmed by Maja Bauge, the director of the Kon-Tiki Museum in Oslo.
abstract: Knut Haugland, sailor on 1947 Kon-Tiki expedition and leader in Norwegian resistance during World War II, dies at age 92; photos (M)
headline: Knut Haugland, Sailor On Kon-Tiki, Dies at 92

snippet: Fox’s 3-D science-fiction epic started the new year at No. 1 in domestic ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: Critics may be at odds about the meaning of Fox's 3-D science-fiction epic ''Avatar,'' but its meaning to the box office is clear: It started the new year at No. 1 in domestic ticket sales. With just over $68 million for the weekend, ''Avatar,'' directed by James Cameron, left (in 3-D specs), finished its first 17 days in theaters with $352.1 million, a record for a film in its third week of release, according to Variety. Robert Downey Jr. and Jude Law helped keep ''Sherlock Holmes'' (Warner Brothers) at No. 2 with a little more than $38 million, bringing its total to about $140.7 million. ''Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel'' (Fox) remained at No. 3 in its second week, with $36 million ($157 million, total). Nancy Meyers's romantic comedy ''It's Complicated'' (Universal) finished with $18 million, putting it in fourth place with about $60 million total. And though Sandra Bullock was the top box office draw of 2009, ''The Blind Side'' (Warner Brothers) drew only a little more than $12 million in its seventh week in theaters. Still, it was enough to tip it over the $200 million mark, with $209 million total.
abstract: Variety reports that James Cameron film Avatar was number one in domestic ticket sales, with just over $68 million,over New Year's weekend; photo (S)
headline: 'Avatar' On Top Again

snippet: SIMKO--George. The Bostock Family mourns the death of our dear friend, George Simko. We cherished his zest for life, his great wit and sense of humor, his intellectual curiosity and capacities, and will always remember him with joy and love. He was a...
lead_paragraph: SIMKO--George. The Bostock Family mourns the death of our dear friend, George Simko. We cherished his zest for life, his great wit and sense of humor, his intellectual curiosity and capacities, and will always remember him with joy and love. He was a legend in the advertising and communications industry, serving in many executive positions while being a successful mentor, confidant and partner to scores of colleagues during his remarkable 43 year career. We extend our heartfelt and deepest sympathies to his beloved family. Merilee and Roy Bostock
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMKO, GEORGE

snippet: Hollywood and its high-tech partners are trying to create a digital standard that would let consumers buy or rent a movie once and then play it on any device.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to take a DVD to a friend's house and watch it on his TV. But things are more complicated when digital video downloads are involved. A movie file bought from Blockbuster.com will not work on a Sony HDTV, for example, and videos from iTunes work only on devices with Apple software. At the Consumer Electronics Show, a big high-tech gathering that will begin Wednesday in Las Vegas, Hollywood studios and consumer electronics makers plan to lay out some steps they are taking to simplify this digital future -- and perhaps stem the worrying decline in home entertainment sales.
abstract: Film industry and its high-tech partners address portability limitations on video downloads as consumers move away from physical DVDs as their prime source of viewing movies; fear that consumers may not purchase digital content until they have freedom to carry collections wherever they go, creating further financial stress on industry that is struggling to get footing in digital world; organization of Hollywood studios and technology companies are attempting to address issues through organization Digital Entertainment Content Econosystem; photo (M)
headline: Trying to Add Portability To Movie Files

snippet: As a Coast Guardsman, Mr. Wittek helped battle a fire that threatened New York Harbor, an act of bravery that was recognized six decades later.
lead_paragraph: Seymour Wittek, a former Coast Guardsman who helped battle a fire that threatened to devastate New York Harbor during World War II, and six decades later gained the recognition he coveted for his unit's heroism, died Wednesday at a hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Wittek, who lived in Ossining, N.Y., was 88. His death was announced by the Coast Guard.
abstract: Seymour Wittek, former Coast Guardsman who helped battle fire that threatened to devastate New York Harbor during World War II, dies at age 88; photo (M)
headline: Seymour Wittek, 88, Dies; World War II Hero at Home

snippet: Lawyers for a former UBS banker asked to postpone his prison term, saying he is ready to further cooperate with U.S. authorities in their pursuit of tax cheats.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is weighing whether to ask a federal judge to reduce the jail sentence of a former UBS banker who was a main figure in a wide-ranging tax evasion case against wealthy American clients, a person briefed on the matter said. On Friday, the former banker, Bradley C. Birkenfeld, is scheduled to begin a jail term of three years and four months, several years after he began revealing the details of secret offshore private banking accounts set up by UBS to help clients avoid taxes.
headline: U.S. Is Said to Consider Easing Informant's Term

snippet: Five days of blizzards and avalanches cut off air and sea links to the mainland, stranded dozens of motorists on highways, and even buried a train.
lead_paragraph: Five days of blizzards and avalanches have paralyzed the Russian island of Sakhalin, cutting off air and sea links to the mainland, stranding dozens of motorists on highways, and burying a train, along with three railway workers, under snow drifts 10 feet deep. Sakhalin, a narrow island off the coast of Siberia and just 25 miles from Japan, holds a distinct and somewhat mysterious place in Russia's history. Used for centuries to house prisoners before the discovery of rich offshore energy fields, huge stretches of it remain sparsely populated, covered with taiga forests of fir and birch. It is frequently buffeted by storms that sweep in from the Pacific.
abstract: Air and sea links to mainland are cut off, dozens of motorists are stranded and train and three railway workers are buried as five days of blizzards and avalanches paralyze Russian island of Sakhalin; meteorologists expect blizzard conditions to continue for at least another day; map (M)
headline: Harsh Storm Batters Island Off the Coast Of Russia

snippet: THE INBETWEENS  ''Quantum Cowboy''  (Layered)      You might hear any number of possible precedents in the music of the Inbetweens, a young but serious guitar-bass-drums trio. ''Quantum Cowboy,'' the band's first album to be released on an actual...
lead_paragraph: THE INBETWEENS ''Quantum Cowboy'' (Layered) You might hear any number of possible precedents in the music of the Inbetweens, a young but serious guitar-bass-drums trio. ''Quantum Cowboy,'' the band's first album to be released on an actual label -- Layered Music, out of Madison, Wis. -- offhandedly evokes space rock, surf rock, Ethiopian jazz, Ennio Morricone and Tortoise. (There's some overlap there.) What it might suggest most is an update of the trio led in the early 1990s by the guitarist Bill Frisell, with Kermit Driscoll on bass and Joey Baron on drums.

snippet: SIMKO--George J.,74, passed away at home, surrounded by family, on December 30, 2009. George enjoyed a successful 43-year career in the advertising and marketing communications industry. Starting in the mailroom of Kenyon & Eckhart, Inc. in 1953, he...
lead_paragraph: SIMKO--George J.,74, passed away at home, surrounded by family, on December 30, 2009. George enjoyed a successful 43-year career in the advertising and marketing communications industry. Starting in the mailroom of Kenyon & Eckhart, Inc. in 1953, he rose through the ranks of K&E, and then D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles, Inc., where he spent 36 years. During his career George served in a wide variety of executive positions. He was Director of Media Management at DMB&B in the 1970's when the department was regarded as the leading media and programming operation in the industry. He then was named President of the Diversified Communications Division of DMB&B, overseeing its public relations, sales promotion, direct marketing and health care companies. George finished his career as President of the European and Middle Eastern operations of DMB&B based in London, and Chairman of the Executive Committee of DMB&B, retiring in 1996. George served as a Director of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for 10 years, using his media and programming expertise to help build the 24-hour Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon into one of the most successful fundraising endeavors in television history. He also spent a decade serving on the Board of Directors of the media industry's Audit Bureau of Circulations. Beloved husband of Mary, cherished father of Caroline and Christopher, admired father-in-law of Hans Olsen, honored brother of Ed, Barbara and Raymond, and loving uncle to numerous nieces and nephews. Visitation on Tuesday, January 5 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South Street, Oyster Bay, NY. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, January 6 at St. Dominic R.C. Chapel, 93 Anstice Street, Oyster Bay, NY. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery, Ryefield Road, Locust Valley, NY.
headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMKO, GEORGE J.
